**Comparability of the Financial Statements**

**_Adoption of IFRS 16_**

On January 13, 2016, the IASB published IFRS 16, and the European Union adopted IFRS 16 on
November 9, 2017. We have adopted IFRS 16 from January 1, 2019. Under IFRS 16, we recognize
lease liabilities in relation to leases which had previously been classified as “operating leases” under
the principles of IAS 17 “Leases.” We recognize a right-of-use asset representing our right to use the
underlying asset and a lease liability representing our obligation to make lease payments. We elected to
apply the modified retrospective approach on transition to IFRS 16, and as such the cumulative effect
of initially applying the standard was recognized at the date of initial application, January 1, 2019,
without an adjustment to our prior-year results. The adoption of IFRS 16 had an impact on our balance
sheets, income statements and cash flow statements. As a result, the comparability of our income
statement information between these periods is limited because our adoption of IFRS 16 on January 1,
2019, resulted in an increase of interest expense on leases, an increase of depreciation of lease assets
and a decrease of rent expense on operating leases. In addition, the comparability of our balance sheet
information between these dates is limited because our adoption of IFRS 16 on January 1, 2019, resulted
in an increase in current and non-current other financial liabilities. To facilitate a comparison of our
results of operations and financial condition across periods and irrespective of the applicable lease
accounting standard, we present in this Offering Memorandum certain financial information for the
years ended December 31, 2019 and 2020, the three months ended March 31, 2020 and 2021, and the
twelve months ended March 31, 2021 on a Pre-IFRS 16 basis, which has been adjusted to exclude the
impact of IFRS 16. In addition, we believe this Pre-IFRS 16 financial information reflects our financial
condition and financial performance in a more accurate manner than under IFRS 16. These figures have
not been prepared in accordance with IFRS or any other generally accepted accounting principles and
are presented for illustrative purposes only. See “Summary—Summary Financial and Other Data” and
the Financial Statements and the related notes included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum.

**_COVID-19_**

The COVID-19 pandemic has significantly impacted our business. As a result, the comparability of our
results for the financial year ended December 31, 2020 and the three months ended March 31, 2021
with the relevant corresponding periods in 2019 and 2020, respectively, is limited. In addition, the
COVID-19 pandemic may impact comparability of past results with future periods. See “Management’s
_Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—COVID-19 Impact on Our_
_Business” and “Summary—Impact of the COVID-19 Pandemic.” To provide investors with a more_
normalized overview of our business and results of operations, in this Offering Memorandum, we
mainly present and discuss operational and financial data as of and for the year ended December 31,
2019, which was the last full period under discussion that was unaffected by the COVID-19 pandemic.

**Revision of the 2019 Financial Information**

On January 1, 2019, we applied IFRS 16 Leases for the first time. In this context, rental payments for
airports in Norway were classified as quasi-fixed under IFRS 16.B42(a)(ii). In the 2020 Audited

##### xx


-----

Consolidated Financial Statements, we determined that this classification was inaccurate as the
payments are variable payments that are not included in the lease payments for purposes of calculating
the lease liability and, subsequently, the right-of-use asset. Rather, variable lease payments that are not
included in the measurement of the lease liability are recognized by the lessee in profit or loss in the
period in which the event or condition that triggers these payments occurs (IFRS 16.38). As a
consequence, the calculated deferred taxes also changed. Accordingly, our balance sheet as of
December 31, 2019 overstates items of assets as well as liabilities and in the consolidated statement of
comprehensive income, depreciation for rights of use assets and the interest expense for lease liabilities
are reduced. Previously, lease expenses as well as expenses for materials and purchased services for
office rent and incidental expenses were reported under other expenses. From the year ended December
31, 2020 onwards, lease expenses, expenses for materials and purchased services for office rent and
incidental expenses are reported directly in their own line items, and the previous years are adjusted
accordingly. In addition, the adjusted consolidated cash flow statement shows a reduced cash flow from
operating activities, while the cash flow from financing activities is relieved of interest and repayments
of the lease liability, with net cash flow remaining unchanged. For a reconciliation, see note 9 to our
2020 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements.

Accordingly, our historical financial information as of and for the year ended December 31, 2019
presented in this Offering Memorandum has been extracted from the comparative column in our 2020
Audited Consolidated Financial Statements and differs from the historical financial information as of
and for the year ended December 31, 2019 presented in our 2019 Audited Consolidated Financial
Statements.

**Non-GAAP Measures**

This Offering Memorandum contains certain non-GAAP measures and ratios, including EBT, EBIT,
EBITDA, EBITDA excluding effects from the application of IFRS 16, Pre-IFRS 16 Adjusted EBITDA,
Pre-IFRS 16 Adjusted EBITDA margin and Pro Forma Pre-IFRS 16 Adjusted EBITDA (collectively,
the “EBITDA Measures”), as well as capital expenditures, adjusted free cash flow (before expansion
capital expenditure), adjusted free cash flow, adjusted cash conversion, adjusted operating cash flow,
Contract Contribution and other measures and ratios that are not required by, or presented in accordance
with, IFRS (collectively with our EBITDA Measures, the “Non-GAAP Measures”). In addition,
EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Pre-IFRS 16 Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Pre-IFRS 16 Adjusted
EBITDA as presented in this Offering Memorandum differ from the definition of “Consolidated
EBITDA” that will be contained in the Indenture. Such Non-GAAP Measures are presented based on
information derived from the Financial Statements, our historical accounting records and our internal
accounting system.

We believe the Non-GAAP Measures provide supplemental information which may be useful in the
review of the Issuer’s financial performance described in this Offering Memorandum and are useful
metrics for investors to understand our results of operations and profitability because they permit
investors to evaluate our profitability from underlying operating activities. We also use these measures
internally to establish forecasts, budgets and operational goals to manage and monitor our business, as
well as to evaluate our underlying historical performance. For a description of how the Non-GAAP
Measures are calculated from our consolidated results of operations and a reconciliation of the NonGAAP Measures to our results of operations for the periods presented in this Offering Memorandum,
see “Summary—Summary Financial and Other Data.”

We believe the Non-GAAP Measures facilitate operating performance comparisons between periods
and among other companies in industries similar to ours because they remove the effect of variation in
capital structures, taxation, and non-cash depreciation, amortization and impairment charges, which
may be unrelated to operating performance. We believe the Non-GAAP Measures better reflect our
underlying operating performance because they exclude the impact of items which are not related to
our core results of operations, including certain one-off or non-recurring items. The Non-GAAP
Measures or comparable measures are frequently used by securities analysts, investors and other
interested parties in their evaluation of companies comparable to us, many of which present EBITDA
Measures when reporting their results.

The Non-GAAP Measures presented in this Offering Memorandum are based on assumptions, opinions,
estimates, projections and forecasts which involve known and unknown operational, business,
economic, regulatory and other risks, uncertainties and other factors that could cause actual results,
performance or achievements to be materially different from future results, performance or
achievements expressed or implied by such Non-GAAP Measures. These Non-GAAP Measures have
been prepared, in good faith, based on numerous assumptions that, while considered reasonable by the
Issuer at the time of preparation, may or may not prove to be correct or necessarily take place.

##### xxii


-----

In addition, the Non-GAAP Measures have limitations as analytical tools, and you should not consider
them in isolation or as a substitute for analysis of our results or any directly comparable financial
measures prepared in accordance with IFRS as set forth in the Financial Statements. Some of these
limitations are:

- not all of them reflect our cash expenditures and they do not reflect our future requirements for
capital expenditures on contractual commitments;

- they may include cost savings which are based on various assumptions that we consider
reasonable, but these cost savings may not be achieved in the expected timeframe, or at all, as
a result of future unexpected changes in our business or other factors;

- assets are depreciated or amortized over differing estimated useful lives and often have to be
replaced in the future, and these measures do not reflect any cash requirements for such
replacements;

- they do not reflect changes in, or cash requirements for, our working capital needs;

- they do not reflect the interest expense or cash requirements necessary to service interest or
principal payments on our debt;

- they do not reflect any cash income taxes that we may be required to pay;

- they are not adjusted for all non-cash income or expense items that are reflected in our
consolidated statements of profit or loss and other comprehensive income;

- they do not reflect the impact of earnings or charges resulting from certain matters we consider
not to be indicative of our ongoing operations;

- some of the non-recurring items that we eliminate in calculating certain EBITDA Measures
reflect cash payments that were made, or will in the future be made; and

- other companies in our industry may calculate these measures differently than we do, limiting
their usefulness as comparative measures.

Because of these limitations, the Non-GAAP Measures should not be considered as measures of
discretionary cash available to us to invest in the growth of our business or as measures of cash that will
be available to us to meet our obligations. You should compensate for these limitations by relying
primarily on our IFRS results and using the Non-GAAP Measures only supplementally to evaluate our
performance. See “Summary—Summary Financial and Other Data,” “Management’s Discussion and
_Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations” and the Financial Statements and the notes_
thereto included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum.

**Exchange Rate Information**

The majority of our sales revenues is denominated in currencies other than the euro, which is the Issuer’s
presentational and functional currency. The individual financial statements of each subsidiary of the
Issuer are presented in their functional currency. For more information on our currency exchange rate
exposure, see “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of
_Operations—Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Financial Risk Management—Currency_
_Risks.”_

The results of operations and cash flows of subsidiaries which have non-euro functional currencies are
translated at the average monthly exchange rates during the year. The balance sheet of each subsidiary
which has a non-euro functional currency is translated at year-end exchange rates, with the exception
of equity balances which are translated at historic rates. The resulting exchange differences are

##### xxiii


-----

recognized in a separate currency translation reserve within equity and are reported in other
comprehensive income.

As of the end of the reporting period, assets and liabilities of foreign operations are translated into the
functional currency at the exchange rate as of the reporting date. The income and expenses of foreign
operations are translated into the functional currency at the exchange rates as of the dates of the
transactions. Foreign currency differences are recognized in other comprehensive income accumulated
in reserve. At the time of disposal of a foreign operation, any accumulated currency-translation
differences are transferred to profit or loss as part of the gain or loss on disposal.

**Overview**

We are a leading parking infrastructure operator and services provider in the European market, with a
large and diversified portfolio of leased and managed parking facilities across 13 European countries.
We operate off-street parking facilities under leases from private and public landlords, and also operate
on- and off-street parking facilities for clients under management contracts. As of March 31, 2021, we
operated approximately 11,700 parking facilities with over 1.6 million parking spaces. We believe we
are either the leading or number two parking facility operator by number of parking spaces in each of
our ten largest country markets.

We benefit from a large, structurally attractive and growing parking market that we believe will benefit
from ongoing outsourcing, mobility and other industry trends such as growth in the number of vehicles
in Europe, urban areas, electric vehicle (“EV”) charging, car hiring and sharing and more recently use
of the car parks as infrastructure for the e-commerce value chain and customer delivery. During 2018,
the European parking market generated approximately €28 to 29 billion in revenues of which
approximately €11 to 12 billion was spent on outsourcing parking management. We believe we are well
positioned to capture the benefits from these trends and the general economic recovery from the
COVID-19 pandemic expected in 2021 and 2022 because we create significant, stable and recurring
value for our clients, for whom parking facilities are often a non-core operation, by providing a large
scale platform that is focused on driving higher revenues by increasing volume, pricing and utilization,
at a lower cost of operation.

Our operations benefit from a diverse portfolio of lease and management contracts as well as
geographical, business sector and customer diversification, which made our business more resilient
during the COVID-19 pandemic, while at the same time allowing us to leverage operational similarities
to benefit from scale economies. Our parking facilities are spread across most of Europe (with certain
clusters for operational efficiency) and apart from one large market (Germany), five other countries
(Denmark, Italy, Sweden, the United Kingdom and Norway) each contributed approximately 10% of
our Pre-IFRS 16 Contract Contribution in the year ended December 31, 2019. We operate in a wide
range of business sectors, such as city and shopping, travel, healthcare & education, events and
hospitality, and parking enforcement, with limited correlation between them. Furthermore, many of our
parking facilities are not dedicated to a single institution, business or purpose but are instead multifunctional and used by motorists that visit a variety of locations, whether it is for work, shopping,
restaurant or cultural activities, or other purposes. We have very low contract concentration, with over
5,900 contracts across over 11,700 parking facilities.

We have made significant investments in recent years in our information technology and digital delivery
in order to make our facilities and services more attractive to both motorists and landlords. We offer
motorists various services related to on-street and off-street parking via smartphone applications and
end customer-oriented websites. These services cover the entire parking customer experience, from
searching for and reserving a parking space, navigating to the parking garage, contactless entry and exit,
and electronic payment. This saves motorists from having to draw a ticket, walk to the ticket machine
or cash machine and pay with cash, making the parking process easier, faster and more comfortable for
the end customer. These digital services also allow for additional yield management through
differentiated pricing according to the number of available spaces, distribution channel, location and
size of specific parking spaces and customer groups.

We operate our clients’ parking assets through two business models, lease contracts and management
contracts. In each of these models, we run parking operations for our clients without incurring
significant capital expenditures and thus through an “asset light” approach that is flexible and scalable,
because we operate the facilities as opposed to owning them. Our long-term underlying contract
structures provide us with stability of revenues and the ability to forecast and plan. As of March 31,
2021, our average contract life (including extensions) for our top 100 contracts (based on weighted
average Pre-IFRS 16 Contract Contribution for the year ended December 31, 2019) was approximately
31 years with an average remaining life of approximately 12 years.

- _Lease Contracts. We lease parking sites from our clients, where we are responsible for running_
the parking operations and driving site-revenue. We receive parking fees directly from the

##### 2


-----

consumers parking in our leased sites and we pay rent to the lessor, either as a fixed rent, a
variable rent or a combination of fixed and variable rent payments. We focus on driving yield
at the site by increasing parking volume and price. We have a mix of short and long-term
parking customers at our leased sites. Short-term parking includes customers who pay on a perhour or per-day basis. Short-term parking generated 53% of our total revenues for the year
ended December 31, 2019. Long-term, or contract parking revenue, includes customers holding
season tickets, including monthly, quarterly and annual season tickets, and individual customers
and business customers who may contract for multiple spaces. Long-term contract parking
generated 11% of our revenues for the year ended December 31, 2019. Short-term parking
customers provide immediate payment in cash, by debit or credit cards, or through payment
apps at the location of our parking facilities. In addition, in some countries, including Norway
and Sweden, short-term parking customers are charged via invoice after the parking event has
been completed, for which we charge an additional fee payable by the consumer. Contract
parking customers provide advance payments which contribute to revenue stability and a
favorable net working capital profile. We are responsible for providing car parking technology
at the site and all expenses relating to operating and maintaining the parking equipment during
the term of the lease, with minimal responsibility for the physical upkeep of the facility and as
a result have limited capital expenditure obligations for maintenance of the facility. Our lease
contract business generated 76% of our revenue for the year ended December 31, 2019.

- _Management contracts. Our management business represents the fees we receive for managing_
parking facilities under contracts with third parties including public authorities as well as
private landlords and other private entities. Under these contracts we also advise on driving
revenue and traffic to the site. We are responsible for running the parking operations and
providing the car parking technology, which is often purchased through us but paid and owned
by the client. We are incentivized to meet a fixed contractual service level for which we receive
a fixed management fee from our client, and may also receive additional incentive fees. We do
not pay rent to our client, and the clients benefit from the fees paid by customers parking their
cars at these locations (which they receive either directly or through us, but which we typically
do not recognize as revenue). At sites under management contracts, we focus on maximizing
operational efficiency and scale and do not bear the risk of reduced traffic volumes and make
limited to no capital investments. Our management contract business generated 24% of our
revenue for the year ended December 31, 2019.

Our parking enforcement services (issuing penalty notices on private land and administering fines in
public spaces) help our clients increase parking compliance and safety and reduce abuse, over-stays and
unwanted parking. These services include the patrolling of parking facilities owned or leased by our
clients, the issuance and collection of parking fines, the management of debt collection and the provision
of impartial representation and appeals services. We offer our parking enforcement services mainly in
Germany, Austria, Belgium, Sweden, Norway, Denmark, Poland and the United Kingdom. In the year
ended December 31, 2019, we generated revenues of €157 million, or 21.8% of our total revenue from
parking enforcement services.

We also provide an extended range of ancillary services, including traffic management, taxi
management, shuttle management, valet parking, trolley services, parking space monitoring, security
and cleaning, advertising space marketing, e-solutions such as online booking platforms, apps and
electronic payment methods, collection services to parking facility owners as well as 24/7 support and
advising property owners on commercial and technical asset management as well as, in certain
circumstances, the planning, financing, construction and operation of multi-storey car parks and parking
spaces.

In addition, we have recently introduced “APCOA Urban Hubs,” which expands our core business
through new partnerships with participants across the mobility, logistics, electrification and technology
sectors. The COVID-19 pandemic led to the acceleration of the e-commerce penetration, on-demand
proximity services, proliferation of new mobility models and increased automation. These services

require substantial city-based infrastructure. Our APCOA Urban Hubs offer this infrastructure with
dedicated parking areas that can be used for alternative services, such as the long-term and short-term
storage of goods, trans-shipping for trucks and electric bikes for last mile deliveries, fleet parking for
logistics companies, shared vehicle and other mobility services and EV charging stations for fleet and
micro mobility like electric scooters and bikes. In addition, APCOA Urban Hubs offer fixed
infrastructure such as the installation of 5G antennas, solar panels and wind energy generation. Our

establishing a new business segment for the use of parking spaces by B2B partners initially with an
increasing B2C offering in the medium term. To date, we have opened 179 APCOA Urban Hubs
focusing primarily on Germany, Denmark and the United Kingdom. As the COVID-19 pandemic has
accelerated the need to find alternative uses for parking spaces, we expect that APCOA Urban Hubs
will be a substantial part of our business going forward, reducing risk by providing further
diversification of our revenue streams. We have recently signed contracts with significant participants
in this evolving market, in addition to pursuing a healthy pipeline of additional Urban Hubs
opportunities.

For the year ended December 31, 2019, our revenue was €720.6 million, our Pre-IFRS 16 Adjusted

**Strengths**

We believe that we have several competitive advantages in the car park sector in Europe, including our
local market leadership positions, long-term contract revenues, resilient and diversified business profile,
advanced digital and technology systems, local density and efficient operations and a strong
management team.

**_Leading Parking Infrastructure Operator in Europe_**

We are one of the leading car park infrastructure operators in the European parking market. We operate
approximately 11,700 parking facilities, and have increased our parking facilities from 1.3 million in
2016 to over 1.6 million parking spaces as of March 31, 2021. We believe we have the leading or second
largest market share by number of parking spaces in each of our ten largest markets. Our leading
position helps provide strong brand value, which has allowed us to achieve above-market growth in
recent years in our key countries. Our well-developed operational capabilities provide us with a highly
scalable platform through which we can add additional facilities and services at a moderate incremental
cost. We have been able to efficiently consolidate other European parking operations by acquiring
smaller operators, including Real Estate Schaffhausen GmbH, Alpina Deutschland GmbH, OnePark
A/S, Security Park AS, Profectum AS, Nationwide Controlled Parking Systems Limited, Mobile
Research Solutions Limited and Xpert Parkering Sweden AB. We have a large presence in the top cities
by population in each of our markets, which leads to density-related synergies. Our pan-European
presence allows us to serve our clients across a wide range of European geographies and makes us a
partner of choice for key pan-European property owner and investor corporate accounts. We believe
that our attractive locations, digital offering with direct customer interactions and internal data on
frequencies and customer behavior help us drive favorable pricing.

We are able to use our scale to operate our car park portfolio in an efficient manner, which allows us to
realize synergies and also makes us an attractive partner for our clients. For example, our scale enables
us to share resources among our car parks (in particular, in clusters where we operate multiple parking
facilities in close proximity) including maintenance and supervisory staff, as well as management
resources in respect of parking customer service, client support, accounting, marketing, human
resources, insurance and tax matters. Due to our size and scale, we are better equipped to make
significant investments in IT and parking lot technology and to leverage such investments across our
operations compared to smaller competitors. Our information technology services cover the entire
parking customer experience from searching for and reserving a parking space through to navigating to
the parking garage, contactless entry and exit and electronic payment. In 2018 we launched our APCOA

##### 4


-----

FLOW platform, which is based on a central, open and scalable digital platform which connects the
vast majority of our leased parking garages, including parking technology, with its customers and their
vehicles via a cloud solution including smartphone apps. We are also in the process of upgrading our
APCOA Flow platform to provide real time data on occupancy and availability of our parking facilities,
thereby enabling us to better anticipate and predict customer demand. APCOA FLOW also provides us
with a direct channel to our end customers, allowing us to offer tailor-made products, differentiated
prices and convenience thereby increasing customer loyalty and frequency of use. These operational
efficiencies and incremental revenues generated through information technology initiatives and
investments allow us to offer a compelling product to customers and landlords. APCOA FLOW is also
a key element of our new APCOA Urban Hubs initiative.

**_Large and Structurally Attractive Growing Market_**

During 2018, the European parking market generated approximately €28 to 29 billion in revenues, with
approximately €11 to 12 billion spent on outsourcing parking management of which over €6 billion was
spent on off-street management in our top six markets. The European parking market grew by 4-5%
annually from 2013 to 2018, primarily as a result of new outsourcing, increased pricing and increased
volume through better utilization and new builds, in particular in larger cities. We expect that
outsourcing will continue to increase as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, as clients seek to lower
their costs by partnering with operators like us who can provide economies of scale and provide
alternative uses such as through our APCOA Urban Hubs initiative. The countries in which we operate
have seen steady parking revenue growth and increasing personal car fleet levels over the past decade.
The large and growing car fleet in Europe included over 240 million vehicles in 2019. From 2013 to
2019, the number of passenger car registrations in Europe increased by between 12 and 15 million
vehicles per year. In 2020 this trend was interrupted by the COVID-19 pandemic. See “Summary—
_Impact of the COVID-19 Pandemic.” The off-street parking industry in Europe is highly fragmented_
with a limited number of large players who have the scale to operate their business as efficiently as we
do.

Our client acquisition strategy is largely focused on first time outsourcing. We believe there is continued
strong outsourcing penetration potential in Europe, as currently approximately 50% of the European
parking market by revenue is run by business or property owners and not otherwise outsourced to
specialized parking operators. In addition, we believe that there will be continued growing demand for
outsourcing in parking due to the increased adoption of technologies, the increased consumer demand
for digital services, the increased level of sophistication required in yield management, increased budget
pressure on municipalities and the necessity to decrease costs through economies of scale.
Approximately 80% of our average Pre-IFRS 16 Contract Contribution from new business during 2018,
2019 and 2020 results from first time outsourcing.

We believe that off-street parking is expected to benefit from key trends in the industry, including, for
example: the regulatory shift away from on-street parking with reduced on-street parking provisions in
city centers, increasing prices of on-street parking and the introduction of electric cars, which require
EV charging spaces that off-street parking can offer. As a result, based on the market report prepared
by an international management consultant firm, outsourced parking consumer spend is expected to
grow at a CAGR of approximately 4% between 2018 and 2023.

We also believe that parking facilities will benefit from the ongoing transformation of off-street car
park facilities into multi-modal urban hubs. We have focused on four case-use groups to increase our
revenue derived from urban hubs: mobility modality, new technology and services, logistics and
electrification. Modality improvements provide inter-modal and multi-modal transports from one
location. Ride share providers use parking facilities as hubs to provide these journeys, or rent shared
cars, electric scooters or bikes from these facilities. New technology and services involves integrating
proximity and community services from our locations through our digital platform. In addition, in
October 2020 we demonstrated, together with Bosch/Daimler, automated valet parking for vehicles
with autonomous driving capabilities at Stuttgart airport. Logistics services includes using urban
facilities as fulfillment centers for logistics, storage and distribution services, such as Amazon drop
boxes and overnight delivery package storage. Electrification includes providing connected charging
services for EVs, fleet and micro mobility like electric scooters and bikes. We currently provide
consumers access to over 2,000 third-party owned charging stations at our parking facilities, which is
being further expanded.

There are significant barriers to entry for new entrants in the car park industry in Europe, including
required investments in building the required operational know-how and digital infrastructure and the
economies of scale that result from achieving local density. In addition, our long-standing relationships
with our clients enable an ongoing dialogue with them as contracts approach renewal and provide us
with an opportunity to sign pre-emptive renewals usually involving upgrading the parking equipment
in return for a new long-term contract. Our focus on outsourcing, not ownership, allows us to develop
key accounts for whom we operate multiple locations across multiple geographies.

We believe our limited reliance on any single geography, customer base or contract helps reduce our

We believe we are well-positioned for a recovery from the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic due to

**_Asset-Light Business Model With a Flexible Cost Base and Optimal Return on Capital_**

We operate our clients’ parking assets through two business models: lease contracts and management
contracts. For the year ended December 31, 2019, our operations under lease contracts generated 76%
of our revenues, and operations under our management contracts generated 24% of our revenues. In
each of these models, we run parking operations for our clients without incurring significant capital
expenditures and through an asset light approach that is flexible and scalable, because we operate the
facilities as opposed to owning them. Our asset light model benefits from an attractive payback period
of approximately one year on new business investments, mainly in parking and equipment technology.
Our long-term underlying contract structures provide visibility and stability and we seek to negotiate
for contractual flexibility in the event of material adverse changes on sites that are outside of our control.
For the facilities we operate under leases, we generate our fees based on tariffs charged directly to car
park users, which allows us to apply our yield management expertise to increase volumes and prices.
We have a balanced level of fixed lease costs (42% of fixed rent as a percentage of total rent in the year
ended December 31, 2019 on a pre-IFRS 16 basis) because most of our leases provide for a mix of fixed

##### 7


-----

and variable rent payments, the variable portion of which is based on the actual revenue earned by us
at the location subject to the lease. For the year ended December 31, 2019, 58% of our €345 million of
pre-IFRS 16 rent expense was variable rents. In the year ended December 31, 2020, when our business
was adversely affected by the COVID-19 pandemic, the variable rents provided an immediate expense
buffer with our variable rent expense decreasing by €111 million compared to our original budgeted
variable rent expense for the period. In the year ended December 31, 2020, 46% of our pre-IFRS 16
rent expense was variable. The management fees charged by us under our management contracts
typically increase each year in line with inflation, and often include additional incentive fees depending
on the performance of the facility. Compared to the substantial decrease in our lease contract revenue
due the COVID-19 pandemic, our management contract revenue during the year ended December 31,
2020 only decreased by 10% compared to the previous year, as our clients continued to need our
services and were required to make payments despite lower parking volumes.

**_Strong Financial Profile, with Successful Management Execution resulting in Growth, Profitability_**
**_and High Cash Conversion_**

Our business model provides us with long-term cash flow visibility as a result of our strategic focus on
operating our facilities through long-term contracts, recurring business through seasonal parking
customers, parking playing a central role in the local economy as well as our ability to accurately
estimate our revenue and profitability and analyze trends in working capital and capital expenditure.
Our long-term cash flow visibility is furthered by the favorable and stable regulatory environment in
the markets in which we operate as well as by certain contractual protections for us in our lease and
management contracts.

Between 2015 and 2019, we achieved 20 quarters of consecutive year-on-year profit growth up to the
end of 2019 (measured on the basis of Pre-IFRS 16 Contract Contribution). Parking demand in a
particular market is typically correlated to the total size of the car fleet in that market (rather than GDP),
which enhances the stability of our revenues over long periods and helps provide resilience through
periods of economic downturn. Our revenue has benefitted from positive structural trends such as
increasing motor vehicle fleet in our markets, a move from on-street parking to off-street parking and
increasing levels of outsourcing, but it has also benefitted from the successful implementation of
strategic expansions by our management team, focusing on clients who outsource operations or
management of their parking facilities for the first time, and achieving high retention rates of typically
over 95% for the past five years. In addition, between 2015 and 2019, we increased our Pre-IFRS 16
Adjusted EBITDA profit margin from 8.8% to 11.6%, primarily as a result of the implementation of
cost savings and operational efficiency measures and better yield management through, for example,
dynamic pricing that we offer across 69 of our sites, all of which were implemented by our current
management team which joined in 2016 and early 2017. Our revenue increased at a CAGR of 2.3%
between 2016 and 2019, primarily driven by like-for-like growth and the acquisitions of OnePark A/S
and Nationwide Controlled Parking Systems Limited, offset by the non-renewal of our contract with
Oslo Airport, which we decided not to pursue aggressively due to low margins. This like-for-like
revenue growth was driven by a combination of tariff increases, length of stay and volume management
across all core countries. In addition, between January 2019 and March 31, 2021, we completed five
bolt-on acquisitions with attractive synergies. We believe our scale, stability and industry experience
facilitates our ability to win new business, with a 75% win rate in 2020 for all contracts bid on.

Our management team has also implemented a differentiated approach to both our key pan-European
and local clients, which has resulted in an increase in the share of new business that is generated from
relationships with key accounts. For the year ended December 31, 2020, approximately 60% of our new
business was generated by key accounts, compared to 11% in 2016. We typically have separate
agreements for each of our facilities with our key accounts, with differing durations and renewal dates.
We believe we have strong relationships with our key accounts and that there is continued growth
potential. As of March 31, 2021, we had over 4,800 clients.

Our parking facilities, once operational, require relatively low levels of capital expenditures. Our
limited maintenance capital expenditures, which averaged less than 1% of revenue in the years ended

December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020 are driven by the capital-light nature of our business. Our cash flow
generation benefits from an advantageous working capital cycle through the collection of upfront
payments (through season tickets) from our long-term parking customers and revenue collection

**_Clear Strategy Targeting Low-Risk Growth Opportunities from Multiple Sources_**

We believe we are well positioned to continue expanding our business by targeting a diverse range of
low-risk growth opportunities across our traditional parking markets and expanding our new APCOA
Urban Hubs initiative.

We expect that demand for traditional parking across our sectors will continue to normalize as
vaccination programs are now well underway across all of our countries, with more than 50% of the
adult population in each of our top six countries having received at least one dose of the COVID-19
vaccine. Accordingly, we continue to monitor growth opportunities in this sector. In addition, despite
the difficult market environment due to the COVID-19 pandemic, we further expanded our contract

portfolio, winning new business contracts in 2020 equivalent to €13.2 million in annualized Pre-IFRS
16 Contract Contribution, which we expect will contribute to our portfolio growth going forward. We
will continue to make technological developments focused on improving service delivery and margins
in our traditional parking sectors, as well as further refine our pricing mechanisms in order to improve
yield. We believe our continued focus on key accounts, with whom we believe we have strong
relationships, and first time outsourcing differentiates us from our competitors and provides continued
growth potential.

We also believe there are growth opportunities in the less traditional parking markets. For example, we
plan to continue our expansion of our parking enforcement services in Scandinavia and roll out ANPRbased services in the rest of Europe for the retail and healthcare sectors in particular.

We also believe we are well positioned to continue growing through our new APCOA Urban Hubs
initiative, which expands our core business through new partnerships with participants across the
mobility, logistics, electrification and technology sectors. The COVID-19 pandemic led to the
acceleration of the e-commerce penetration, on-demand proximity services, proliferation of new
mobility models and increased automation. These services require substantial city-based infrastructure,
which we are ideally placed to provide at a lower cost than our partners could find for many other types
of infrastructure. Our APCOA Urban Hubs offer this infrastructure with dedicated parking areas that
can be used for alternative services. Our wide network of parking facilities, proximity to consumers and
digital capabilities provide a strong asset to these partnerships.

**_Experienced Management Team_**

Our executive management and country management teams have significant experience and
understanding of the car park sector and have a combined experience of over 150 years in the industry,
of which the country management team has over 130 years of experience in the industry. Our executive
management team has focused on increasing revenues through creating a much wider contract pipeline
combined with a higher new project win rate, an increased retention rate, consistent like-for-like growth,
cost optimization and selective strategic acquisitions. We have increased our focus on managing
existing contracts efficiently and have implemented a reward-based culture that promotes excellence
among our local management teams. We have adopted a differentiated approach to pan-European and
local key accounts. As a result, from the year ended December 31, 2016 to the year ended December
31, 2019, our Pre-IFRS 16 Adjusted EBITDA increased at a CAGR of 9.5%. Our management team
has also sought to anticipate and embrace new trends and technology in the car park sector and uses for
our facilities, which has enabled us to be a pioneer in the deployment of efficient pricing, revenue
management, digitalization programs and user-friendly applications.

In addition, our local management teams are well connected to industry bodies and groups as well as
municipalities and maintain strong and long-standing local relationships with the relevant regulatory
authorities in the jurisdictions in which we operate. We benefit from the extensive sector expertise of
our operational managers.

**Strategy**

Our key strategies are as follows:

**_Increase Like-for-Like Sales at our Existing Facilities_**

We plan to continue to seek to increase like-for-like growth at our existing facilities by increasing
volume, effectively managing pricing, creating a differentiated parking experience through digital
parking tools and targeted marketing campaigns. Dynamic pricing has developed as an important
instrument to optimize pricing and yield, and we plan to continue to refine our pricing mechanisms.
Depending on various factors such as day of the week, time of day, occupancy or specific space location
and size, parking tariffs can be dynamically adjusted at car park and specific space level. We plan to

##### 10


-----

continue to seek ways to manage demand at the individual car park level through efficient pricing as
we believe dynamic pricing offers significant revenue enhancement potential.

We plan to continue to implement measures that seek to create a seamless customer experience. We
have invested in ANPR and our APCOA FLOW mobile application, allowing frictionless and ticketless
entry, exit and payment. Besides automatic number plate recognition, customers can access our sites
through radio-frequency identification (“RFID”), Bluetooth or quick response (“QR”) codes. In
addition, we have installed several user-friendly information technology applications to enhance the
customer experience at our car parks, including electronic payment devices. We have installed cashless
and contactless payment mechanisms and have begun using differentiated parking tariffs based on
supply and demand. Over 3 million customers have downloaded our apps to benefit from this increased
convenience. We plan to continue to implement these initiatives at more of our parking facilities and to
continue to develop new ways to make our parking facilities more attractive to customers.

In addition, at many of our facilities we have installed a robust infrastructure of charging facilities for
EVs. The installation and capital expenditure costs are usually covered by our partners, the revenues
from the sale of electricity is shared between us and our partners and we benefit from additional parking
tariffs. In Denmark and Sweden, customers can use our APCOA FLOW app to pay for the electricity
when charging their EVs at one of our facilities or across our partners’ networks, and we are in the
process of implementing this feature in Norway. We believe providing these services will increase
frequency at our sites by offering differentiated and environmentally-friendly services to customers who
own electric and hybrid vehicles, broadening our consumer base.

**_Retain Existing Clients and Grow New Business Pipeline_**

Our retention rates in 2019 and 2020 for our leases and management contracts were approximately 98%,
which shows the stability of our underlying business. We have adopted a differentiated approach to key
pan-European and local clients in order to ensure that we are retaining key accounts. We plan to seek
to continue to retain clients through forward-thinking account management and will continue to
proactively analyze our clients’ infrastructure to ensure we are addressing their needs.

Due to our market leading position, scale, high quality operations, competitive contract pricing and
smart technology offering, we believe that we are well positioned to continue to grow our diversified
portfolio by capturing new contracts in value enhancing locations from both existing clients seeking to
award new contracts and from organizations looking to outsource the management of their parking
facilities, including first time outsourcers. Due to our scale, long-standing industry experience and local
density, we believe we are able to achieve significant synergies that allow us to offer competitive terms
and win new business. Our selection of facility locations is driven by our long-term strategy to operate
and expand in high margin locations and seek local density. Despite the effect of the COVID-19
pandemic on our business, in the year ended December 31, 2020 and the three months ended March 31,
2021 we signed new contracts which we estimate will contribute an aggregate amount of approximately
€53.6 million to our revenue and approximately €13.2 million to our Pre-IFRS 16 Contract Contribution
and approximately €14.8 million to our revenue and approximately €3.9 million to our Pre-IFRS 16
Contract Contribution, respectively. On average, the Pre-IFRS 16 Contract Contribution margin of new
business won during 2020 is approximately 500bps above the existing core portfolio of contracts as of
2019. Our current unweighted pipeline of new contracts has constantly remained high at approximately
€75 million of Pre-IFRS 16 Contract Contribution since January 2020 and over €65 million since the
fourth quarter in 2018.

We plan to expand our operations by capturing new opportunities that meet our stringent investment
criteria, including sites that enhance our pricing strategy through a resilient local competitive dynamic,
permit operational cost reductions given our ability to have a single work force servicing multiple
locations and maintain strong relationships with local landlords. In addition, we are often able to expand
our locations to further facilities once we have entered a local market by virtue of our existing
relationships with local landlords and the ability to benefit from synergies with existing parking
facilities. There is also a large opportunity in the transfer of unpaid parking to paid parking, mainly in

##### 11


-----

the retail space as well as in underused office and residential buildings. We will seek to grow
opportunities from first time outsourcing by persuading clients to launch paid parking, effectively
creating new markets.

We believe that we are able to serve a broader market of companies than most traditional operators due
to our focus on operating as opposed to owning the car parks. We believe that our focus on operations
allowed us to establish unique relationships with our large clients as, contrary to certain traditional
operators, we do not compete with our landlords for the purchase of available car park real estate. These
established relationships with private and municipal landlords allow us to be in a better position than
certain of our competitors to secure contracts relating to our landlords’ newly acquired car parks. In
addition, we have introduced a number of initiatives to expand our operations. For example, our
APCOA Urban Hubs initiative extends the use of the parking facilities we operate beyond the core
function of “parking,” providing alternative uses for parking spaces that are unused, such as short term
storage of goods, shared vehicle and other mobility services, EV charging stations and the installation
of 5G antennas. We plan to continue to seek to transform additional parking areas into urban hubs and
expect that APCOA Urban Hubs will be a substantial part of our business going forward.

We believe our position as one of the leading operators of parking facilities in Europe, combined with
our long-standing relationships with a diverse group of landlords and local authorities and favorable
industry dynamics, including high barriers to entry, as well as our new initiatives, will provide us with
a number of opportunities to grow our contract base and pipeline of new opportunities.

**_Continue to Seek Accretive Acquisition Opportunities_**

We plan to continue to selectively identify and target acquisition opportunities in order to increase our
scale. We believe there is still a high level of fragmentation in the European market for parking space
management. The majority of providers are local operators with fewer than 20 car parks. As a result,
we believe we have potential for growth through further consolidation. In 2020 we acquired Security
Park Group in Norway and Xpert Parkering in Sweden, with both businesses delivering a positive
EBITDA in 2020. We plan to continue to seek EBITDA enhancing, value accretive, highly synergistic
acquisitions.

**_Enhance Mobility Solutions and Partnerships_**

We are currently expanding our core business under the brand “APCOA Urban Hubs.” Through this
program, we seek to open up our physical and digital parking infrastructure to partners who are seeking
and are in need of city based infrastructure to support their operations or to deliver consumer based
services. Specifically, partners seek to use our parking areas for logistics, vehicle and other mobility,
electrification and new technology services. Examples include locker boards, logistics fleet parking and
EV charging stations, long-term storage and the installation of 5G antennas. What these services all
offer in common is that, by linking the physical infrastructure with the digital infrastructure, an
alternative use of the parking areas is enabled that extends beyond the core function of “parking.” We
believe that as a result of the trends of urbanization, new mobility and increasing e-commerce, our panEuropean network, comprising more than 11,700 parking facilities, offers great development potential
for our company and its partners. We will continue to seek to transform additional parking areas into
urban hubs.

**Impact of the COVID-19 Pandemic**

The COVID-19 pandemic has significantly impacted our results. Beginning in February (in Italy and at
airports) and March (in our other markets) 2020, car park usage in Europe reduced drastically as a result
of the restrictions on movement and other social distancing measures imposed by governments in
Europe in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. Car park usage at our facilities was similarly affected
in this period. We recorded a decrease in sales revenues of €188.7 million, or 26.2% (€180.1 million
decrease, or 25.4%, on a constant currency basis), from €720.6 million for the year ended December
31, 2019 to €531.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, due to reductions in vehicle parking

##### 12


-----

following the lockdowns resulting from the COVID-19 pandemic. See “Management’s Discussion and
_Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Analysis of Operating Results—_ _Year_
_ended December 31, 2019 compared with the year ended December 31, 2020” for more information._

While our Contract Contribution from management contracts and revenues from long-term parking
remained fairly stable throughout the year, our short-term parking revenues in our lease sites were
strongly impacted by the stringent government lockdown measures to contain the virus. For a number
of weeks early in 2020 our short-term parking revenues from leased sites came to a virtual standstill as
people worked from home and were only allowed or advised to go out for essential or permitted
purposes. The effect of these measures was most severe in the period March to May 2020. Following
the easing of restrictions during the second quarter of the year, customers immediately started to return
to our facilities resulting in a strong recovery of our short term parking revenues and cash flow. This
recovery continued over summer 2020. Although we were still impacted by the absence of public events
(cinemas, theatres and large-scale gatherings), working from home policies and continued restrictions
on travel, short-term parking revenues in the third quarter of 2020 reached on average 80% of levels in
the comparable period in 2019. Increasing infections and hospitalizations led to the reinstatement of
government restrictions from October 2020 onwards, with all our geographic markets experiencing
various degrees of lockdowns, which in turn caused short term parking revenues to decline again. In the
three months ended March 31, 2021, our operations continued to be impacted due to the movement
restrictions imposed by governments as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, which resulted in a
reduction in frequencies and volumes at the sites we operate, and consequently in revenues, compared
to the prior period.

We took measures at an early stage to limit the negative impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on our
employees, operations and business development. Specifically, home office regulations for office staff
were introduced in order to protect customers and employees, operational personnel were switched to
multi-shift operation, and hygiene measures in offices and parking garages were intensified. We sought
to keep our parking facilities open as much as possible as people were advised to avoid public transport
and we took measures to decrease physical contact points by enabling and promoting digital payment
and contactless and cashless parking and payment solutions.

Our management reacted quickly to the COVID-19 pandemic and established a cross-functional
COVID-19 response team, which focuses on safeguarding the health and safety of our employees and
consumers and limiting the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on our business. In particular in March
2020, management implemented strict cash management controls, including (i) a bottom-up, 17-week
rolling cashflow forecast and (ii) the deferral of non-essential overhead expenses and capital
expenditures, which resulted in a reduction of our non-new business capital expenditures to €17.7
million (compared to €22.6 million in the year ended December 2019). These cash management controls
resulted in reductions in total capital expenditures (excluding finance leases) in 2020 compared to the
original budget for that year of €10.3 million, of which €9.9 million was deferred to 2021. In addition,
we implemented stringent operational and overhead cost reduction measures, including an immediate
freeze of all temporary and new hiring, a reduction in headcount of 736 employees, particularly in our
parking attendant and airport staff numbers, and furloughing approximately 22% of our non-directly
revenue generating operational and overhead staff. Furthermore, we leveraged government programs,
such as flexi-time and furlough arrangements and fixed cost recovery support schemes, in order to
further reduce our cost base. These measures resulted in cost reductions compared to the original 2020
budget of approximately €44 million, or 17% of our total non-rent costs, in the year ended December
31, 2020.

In March 2020, we initiated a rent waiver and deferral program across our entire business, which
included the re-negotiation of lease contracts with the aim to defer rent payments and temporarily reduce
or move fixed rent structures to variable rent structures. In addition, we invoked existing contractual
protection clauses, such as clauses allowing rent adjustments in the case of an under-utilization of
parking facilities, to further reduce our rent payments. These rent reduction measures, coupled with the
benefit of reduced variable rent costs due to lower revenues, resulted in rent savings of approximately
€125 million in the year ended December 31, 2020 compared to the original budget for that year.

In May and June 2020, we also raised additional liquidity in an aggregate amount net of costs of €68
million in the form of an additional term loan facility. Furthermore, in May 2020, our ultimate
shareholders, Centerbridge and SVP Global, provided us with an equity injection in the amount of €40
million.

(1) Liquidity includes unrestricted cash on balance sheet and €34 million available for drawing under our Existing Revolving Credit

Despite the difficult market environment, we further expanded our contract portfolio, winning new
business contracts in 2020 equivalent to €13.2 million in annualized Pre-IFRS 16 Contract Contribution,
which we expect will contribute to our portfolio growth going forward. We maintained our historically
high and stable retention rate of typically over 95% in the past five years, signaling the stability of the
underlying business during the COVID-19 pandemic. While the contract profit pool currently remains
underutilized due to COVID-19 related restrictions, the fundamentals of the business are intact and
APCOA’s portfolio is expected to rebound once lock-downs and restrictions on mobility are lifted. As
a result of the pandemic, we accelerated our initiatives to increase our digital presence and provide tools
to offer our customers more flexible, seamless and/or contactless parking solutions. We also
successfully concluded the acquisition of the Security Park Group in December 2020. As a
consequence, we have continued to invest in new business for the future.

Despite our business having been significantly impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic, the past fifteen
months also showed that as soon as restrictions are eased, people quickly start to return to our facilities,
corresponding to a direct recovery in revenues. While the COVID-19 crisis is not over, the spread of
the virus continues and certain government restrictions remain, vaccination programs are now well
underway across all of our countries, with more than 50% of the adult population in each of our top six
countries having received at least one dose of the COVID-19 vaccine. In addition, starting from April
2021 and more visibly from mid- May 2021, we have seen signs of recovery across most of our markets
as countries witnessed an easing of mobility restrictions that had been put in place in response to the
COVID-19 pandemic, including the opening of shopping areas, restaurants and outside events.
Frequencies and movements across all our sectors have been increasing steadily since then. For
example, in our German business, the City and Shopping sectors reached more than 85% of their 2019
levels and the Healthcare & Education sector reached 75% of its 2019 levels, followed by Hospitality
(approximately 60% of 2019 levels), Airports (approximately 30% of 2019 levels) and Events

(approximately 40% of 2019 levels). These trends are further visible in traffic data from major cities,
which shows that traffic is approaching or, in certain cases passing, 2019 levels as mobility continues
to trend towards more normalized levels. As the recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic continues
across all of our markets, we believe we are well-positioned to take advantage of new opportunities in
the European parking market once the lockdown restrictions are eased again.

million for the three months ended June 30, 2020.

Our sales revenue was €39.2 million in the month ended April 30, 2021 (69% of our sales revenue for

during the second half of May, in addition to the benefits of the new business won and acquisitions

**Principal Shareholders**

Centerbridge Partners, L.P. is a private investment management firm employing a flexible approach
across investment disciplines—from private equity to private credit and related strategies, and real
estate—in an effort to develop the most attractive opportunities for its investors. The firm was founded
in 2005 and as of March 31, 2021 has over $30 billion in capital under management with offices in New
York and London. Centerbridge is dedicated to partnering with world-class management teams across
targeted industry sectors and geographies.

Strategic Value Partners, LLC is a U.S.-headquartered investment firm focused on value investments
primarily in Europe and the United States. Founded in 2001 by Victor Khosla, SVPGlobal has invested
more than $30 billion in nearly 450 transactions globally, including $14 billion invested in Europe.
SVPGlobal currently has assets under management of approximately $10 billion, the majority of which
comes through private equity style funds.
