##### RISK FACTORS

_An investment in the Notes involves a high degree of risk. You should carefully consider the following_
_risks, together with other information provided to you in this Offering Memorandum, in deciding_
_whether to invest in the Notes. The occurrence of any of the events discussed below could materially_
_adversely affect our business, results of operations or financial condition. If these events occur, the_
_trading prices of the Notes could decline, and we may not be able to pay all or part of the interest or_
_principal on the Notes, and you may lose all or part of your investment. Additional risks not currently_
_known to us or that we now deem immaterial could also adversely affect our business, results of_
_operations, or financial condition or our ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and affect_
_your investment. Further, to the extent that the COVID-19 pandemic adversely affects our business and_
_results of operations, it may also have the effect of heightening many of the other risks described in this_
_section._

_This Offering Memorandum contains “forward-looking” statements that involve risks and_
_uncertainties. Our actual results may differ significantly from the results discussed in the forward-_
_looking statements. Factors that might cause such differences include those discussed below and_
_elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. See “Forward-Looking Statements.”_

**Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry**

**_The effects of the outbreak of COVID-19 have disrupted our operations, which have had and may_**
**_continue to have a material negative adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial_**
**_condition and prospects._**

The COVID-19 pandemic has had an unprecedented impact on the global economy due to the
implementation of a wide variety of control measures including states of emergency, “shelter in place”
orders, border closures, closures of businesses, and restrictions on commuting, local and international
travel, shopping, social and recreational activities and gatherings. The COVID-19 pandemic has
significantly impacted our results. The volume of traffic at our car parks is dependent on mobility, and
in particular people travelling to locations such as places of employment, shopping centers, leisure
facilities, hospitals, airports, offices and urban areas. Beginning in February at our facilities in Italy and
across Europe at certain airports and at all our other facilities in March, our car park usage reduced
drastically as a result of the restrictions on movement and other social distancing measures imposed by
governments in Europe in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. For a number of weeks early in 2020
our short-term parking revenues came to a virtual standstill because people worked from home, were
only allowed or advised to go out for essential or permitted purposes and most places that people tend
to drive to were no longer accessible. The effect of these measures on the volume of traffic at our
facilities was most severe in the period March to May 2020. Following the easing of restrictions during
the second quarter of the year, customers immediately started to return to our facilities; however at most
we only reached on average 80% of levels of volume of customers at our facilities in the comparable
period in 2019. Travel in the countries in which we operate, however, in the second quarter of 2020
remained significantly below the levels in the comparable period in 2019. Increasing infections and
hospitalizations led to the reinstatement of government restrictions from October 2020 onwards. All the
countries in which we operate experienced various degrees of lockdowns which have continued in many
of the countries in which we operate through the first and second quarters of 2021, which have
significantly negatively impacted our revenues.

The COVID-19 pandemic has subjected our business, results of operations, financial condition and
prospects to a number of risks. The effects of the COVID-19 pandemic have negatively impacted, and
could continue to negatively impact, our revenues and profitability. The impact of the COVID-19
pandemic made it difficult for us to satisfy liquidity requirements during 2020 due to a sharp decline in
our car park usage and could continue to make it difficult for us to satisfy our debt obligations or obtain
financing on favorable terms, or at all, which could generally impact our costs and our ability to increase
revenue in the future. As part of our response to the COVID-19 pandemic, we reduced or postponed
investments and expenses, introduced short-time working and reduced or deferred lease and rental


-----

payments in agreement with landlords and partners. We took out government-guaranteed loans in
Switzerland and benefited from one-off governmental subsidies from various government capital
infusion programs designed to alleviate the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on businesses in the
jurisdictions where we operate. We required an amendment to our credit facility in order to prevent a
default and raised capital from our shareholders and third-party lenders.

Despite the steps we have taken to assess and mitigate the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, the
extent to which the COVID-19 pandemic will continue to impact our business, results of operations,
financial condition or prospects is uncertain. If our business does not generate sufficient cash flows
from operating activities, and financing is not otherwise available to us from borrowings under our
Revolving Credit Facility or other sources, we may not be able to cover our expenses, grow our
business, respond to competitive challenges or fund our other liquidity and capital needs, all of which
would harm our business. The full extent of the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on our business and
financial performance, including our ability to execute our near-term and long-term business strategies
and initiatives in the expected time frame, will depend on future developments, including the duration
and severity of the pandemic, the rollout of vaccines, continued governmental restrictions and new
strains or variants of the disease against which existing vaccines might be ineffective as well as the
extent of the recovery of business and economic conditions in general, all of which are uncertain and
cannot be predicted. We estimate that a partial recovery of the economy may present substantial risks
to our business and operations, as in that scenario occupancy levels at our facilities are likely to remain
below pre-COVID-19 pandemic levels, which would negatively impact our profitability, while our
ability to benefit from governmental assistance would be substantially reduced due to the likelihood of
termination of COVID-19 related financial support programs and furlough schemes. In addition, in that
scenario our landlords may be more reluctant to provide any relief on our lease payments. The potential
effects and long-term impact of COVID-19 could intensify or otherwise affect many of the other risks
set forth herein or present other unforeseen consequences for our business.

**_Changes in individual behavior, including in the aftermath of the COVID-19 pandemic, may lead to_**
**_a decline in parking demand, which could have a material adverse impact on our business, financial_**
**_condition and results of operations._**

New customer behavior, such as an increase in online shopping and working from home, or changes in
the popularity of certain stores or locations, including as a result of permanent store, restaurant or
entertainment venue closures, poses a risk of a decreased demand for parking facilities and may have
an adverse effect on our business and revenue. Changes in customer behavior accelerated during the
COVID-19 pandemic and may continue to do so in the aftermath of the pandemic as the majority of the
population in the markets where we operate has progressively adapted to the restrictive measures
implemented in 2020 and 2021 and has increasingly relied on alternative solutions for leisure and
professional needs. Complete and partial closure of shopping centers, leisure amenities and offices and
the rapid growth of online retail, grocery shopping and food delivery services during the COVID-19
shutdown have resulted in a drastic reduction of visits to city centers. The COVID-19 lockdowns may
have changed shopping behavior for the long-term, and customers may purchase more products online
in the future. For instance, in Germany, since the beginning of the COVID-19 pandemic, trade fairs
have been organized in a different set-up with fewer visitors and a substantial number of main street
venues have gone out of business. Significantly decreased national and international travel, reduction
in the number of flights and the closure of airports has led to the rapid development of remote working
and virtual meetings solutions. Business travel is one of our most profitable business segments, and it
might never fully recover because of the continued use of virtual meetings. Reduced travel will also
impact hotel parking volume and may result in a decrease in parking at large events, such as sporting
events and concerts. These changes in customer behavior and the emergence of alternative solutions for
leisure and professional needs may be permanent or remain for the long-term, which may result in part
of the parking volumes not recovering to the pre-COVID-19 levels in the long-term in each of the
sectors in which we operate, which could have a materially adverse effect on our business.

Reliance by customers on online services and progressive shifts by employers to flexible working
solutions may continue in the aftermath of the COVID-19 pandemic and may result in a decline in

##### 38


-----

parking demand in cities and urban areas as well as transportation hubs such as train stations and
airports, which could have a negative impact on our business. In the twelve months ended December
31, 2019, 11.4% of our revenue was generated by contract parking, where customers have monthly or
annual passes at our facilities. This has generally been a valuable, recurring portion of our revenues. If
many of these customers choose to work from home full-time or even part-time, they may not park in
our facilities any longer, or may not buy monthly or annual passes. Moreover, a slight decrease in the
average parking time that may result from new customer behavior coupled with a lower occupancy rate
of our car parks could have substantial negative impact on our revenue. We have generally relied upon
the historical trends towards urbanization in developing our value-creation initiatives. However, many
people are leaving cities as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic and are choosing to live in rural areas
and work remotely. A material decline in the number of people living in urban areas could have a
material impact on the volume of cars using our facilities. In addition, changing customer habits as a
result of the COVID-19 pandemic that are long-lasting, for example less frequent or shorter shopping
times, utilization of different modes of transportation and reduced in-person gatherings, may have a
materially detrimental effect on our business.

**_General business and economic conditions, including those caused by the COVID-19 pandemic in_**
**_the markets where we operate may decrease demand for parking and may have a material adverse_**
**_effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations._**

Our business, financial condition and results of operations are affected by general business and
economic conditions in the markets in which we operate, in particular in Germany and our other larger
markets. In particular, the long-term economic impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic are unknown at this
time. A downturn in economic conditions resulting in high unemployment rates, reduced customer
spending, increased bankruptcy filings, increased interest rates, high inflation, fluctuations in the
availability or cost of funding, fluctuations in the value of currency or a decline in the strength of
national and local economies in which we operate and other factors that may negatively affect our end
customers’ financial prospects could affect the mobility rates of our end customers. The number of
people visiting shopping centers, restaurants, offices and city centers generally declines during periods
of increased inflation and economic downturn. As a result, a decline in economic conditions could lead
to a decline in the volume of cars parked at our facilities.

**_A large portion of our operations are carried out, and revenue is generated in Europe and Germany,_**
**_in particular. Any adverse political or economic changes within these markets may have an adverse_**
**_effect on our business, results of operations or financial condition._**

All of our business operations are located in Europe. Our business in Germany accounted for
approximately 33% of our Pre-IFRS 16 Contract Contribution in the financial year ended December
31, 2019. In light of this concentration, our business is sensitive to political or economic developments
that effect Europe and Germany in particular. Concerns regarding the debt burden of certain European
countries and their ability to meet future financial obligations, the overall stability of the euro and the
suitability of the euro as a single currency given the diverse economic and political circumstances in
individual member states of the EU could have an outsized adverse effect on our business, results of
operations or financial condition.

**_Customer driven changes in transportation habits may result in a reduction in cars parked at our_**
**_facilities._**

Changes in the transportation industry could have a negative impact on our business, such as increased
use of public transport by end customers and car sharing. The increased use of ride sharing services and
alternative public or private transport providers, and the development of autonomous vehicles, are two
trends that are particularly pronounced in larger cities. Such trends may lead to a decline in parking
demand in cities and urban areas as well as in transportation hubs, such as train stations and airports.
The increase in the accessibility of transportation hubs by alternative public or private transport
providers such as trains, shuttles and ride sharing services may lead to a decreased need for car parks.
Car share programs reduce the need for parking spots as multiple motorists can share a single vehicle.

##### 39


-----

Further development of pedestrian or bike pathways and general green initiatives like congestion
charges which are meant to reduce automobile traffic in urban areas could reduce customers at our car
parks. While we devote considerable effort and resources to analyzing and responding to customer
preferences and changes to customer preferences in the markets in which we operate, customer
preferences cannot be predicted with certainty and can change rapidly. We have invested in positioning
ourselves to benefit from trends such as experience shopping and urbanization, but these trends may
turn out to be less resilient than expected or even may reverse.

**_Significant competition in our markets may adversely affect customers’ desire to park at our_**
**_facilities._**

The parking industry is highly competitive. We believe that customer choice regarding parking is driven
partly by price but also by factors such as location, lighting and security and the ease of parking in
particular as a result of payment apps. Some of our competitors may have greater financial, marketing
and other resources available than us. For example, some of our key competitors include Empark and
Q-Park, each of which has substantial financial, marketing and other resources and established brand
names. Our competitors could use their significant resources to increase their marketing, develop new
services or technology or reduce their prices in a manner that adversely impacts our ability to charge
prices that generate the same margins we have earned in the past, or at all. We cannot assure you that
we will continue to be able to compete successfully against existing or future competitors. Furthermore,
new technology and processes could negatively impact our existing business. For example, continued
use of digital technology to operate parking facilities might diminish the need for physical controls by
our parking officers and therefore the need for certain of our services. In addition, we currently generate
a significant percentage of our revenue from consumers who fail to pay their invoices on time or at all
(i.e., through late fees and related administration fees), which may decrease as more advance parking
technology becomes available. Furthermore, increased use of technology could also lead to new
competitors providing parking services, pushing us towards the role of a facility manager with reduced
spread in the business, which could make our large number of parking facility locations less valuable,
reduce our bargaining powers with our clients and reducing our margins. We also compete with certain
property owners and businesses that operate their own parking facilities. Such entities may be able to
charge lower prices than us because they are seeking to generate revenue through products sold in their
stores, as opposed to parking revenue.

**_Changes in environmental and traffic control regulations could reduce demand for, and volumes in,_**
**_our off-street parking facilities that could adversely affect our business, results of operations or_**
**_financial conditions._**

National or local governments could implement measures which are potentially unfavorable to the
parking sector as a result of pressure from public opinion, advocacy groups, or election results. For
example, proposals relating to limiting traffic within city boundaries or the introduction of bans on
driving of diesel vehicles in certain cities could adversely affect inner-city parking, resulting in lower
revenue and diminished profitability. As an example, a number of car parking spaces in Copenhagen
are expected to be converted to flexible parking spaces for both bicycles and cars. The local authority
in Copenhagen also introduced the “Cyclist Priority Plan for 2017-2025,” which seeks to encourage
50% of commuting journeys to be completed by bicycle. In addition, certain of the cities in which we
operate have introduced dedicated bike lanes in response to changes in traffic patterns and to tackle
environmental concerns. Such initiatives are likely to continue in the future. Governments will likely
continue to implement further measures aimed at reducing car traffic and availability of parking spaces,
additional regulation to provide free parking for staff, patients and visitors at hospitals and other public
places, and regulation with respect to the amount of permitted fines and surcharges that we may charge,
thereby affecting our income.

Some municipalities may impose traffic congestion charges in urban areas, reduce the availability of
on-street parking spaces or promote the use of public transportation in lieu of automobiles. In addition,
certain municipalities may measure and charge for curb time parking, which could encourage courier
and package delivery services to use transportation methods other than cars. Governments may also

##### 40


-----

increase the tax levels on automobiles and petroleum for environmental reasons, which may reduce
traffic. Social perception and pressure relating to environmental concerns over the use of private cars
may similarly adversely impact the demand for our facilities. In addition, municipalities may promote
environmentally-friendly initiatives by reducing the number of parking spaces and encourage the use
of public transport for attendees of large public events and gatherings, trade fairs and transportation
hubs. Furthermore, the government in certain cities may reduce the parking tariffs of their parking
facilities in order to compete with other cities and private companies. We may also be materially
adversely affected by temporary or permanent changes to traffic routes or road closures, which may
make it more difficult to access our parking facilities and have a material adverse effect on our business,
results of operations or financial condition. In addition, during the COVID-19 pandemic, certain
municipalities in Austria and Italy also imposed “free parking” to accelerate the recovery of inner-cities
or to support essential workers. If these free parking arrangements were to be extended or expanded,
our results of operations could be affected.

**_We have a large amount of fixed costs, and if we experience a decrease in our revenue, our operating_**
**_expenses and rent payments will not decrease at the same rate, which could have a material adverse_**
**_effect on our net cash flows, margins and profits._**

Many of the expenses associated with operating parking facilities are relatively fixed. These expenses
include a large portion of our rent expenses, personnel costs, information technology costs, maintenance
and repair and cleaning costs, insurance and utilities. If we are unable to decrease our costs significantly
or rapidly when demand for our parking spaces decreases, the decline in our revenue can have a
particularly adverse effect on our net cash flows and profits. This effect can be especially pronounced
during periods of economic contraction or slow economic growth. Where cost cutting efforts are
insufficient to offset declines in revenue, in particular in respect of our leased car parking facilities, we
could experience a material decline in margins and potentially negative cash flows which could have a
material adverse effect on our business, results of operations or financial condition.

We may also be unable to terminate on short notice or renegotiate unprofitable or disadvantageous
leases or management contracts. In addition, we may be required to honor our contractual lease
provisions or possibly pay considerable amounts in compensation or damages. Furthermore, our
auditors may require us to book onerous contract provisions in relation to unprofitable or
disadvantageous leases or management contracts, which may significantly increase our operating loss.
These lease agreements may negatively impact our profitability, and may have significant adverse
effects on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Furthermore, we may be required to recognize unprofitable or disadvantageous leases or management
contracts as onerous contracts under IAS 37 and record a provision in our financial statements for the
loss we expect to make on such contracts. This may negatively impact our EBITDA and our leverage
ratios under the restrictive debt covenants to which we will be subject and consequently limit our ability
to finance our future operations and capital needs and to pursue business opportunities and activities.
See “—We will be subject to restrictive debt covenants that may limit our ability to finance our future
_operations and capital needs and to pursue business opportunities and activities.”_

**_We are subject to competition that can constrain our ability to acquire new parking facilities, and_**
**_win and renew parking lease contracts, concessions and management contracts for parking services._**

The parking sector in Europe is a competitive market, with a variety of competitors ranging from local
single-facility operators to regional, national and international operators with a significant number of
parking spaces. While the largest owners and operators in the industry are municipalities, other large
competitors include divisions of diversified global corporations with substantial financial, management
and other resources and capabilities.

In Western Europe, many long-term parking lease contracts and management contracts for parking
facilities are awarded and renewed through competitive tenders. A significant number of competing
entities may bid on a parking facility tender. Generally, public tenders for on- and off-street leases and

-----

off-street management contracts are competitive and primarily determined based on economic terms.
Some of our competitors or new entrants to the market may be able to bid at lower prices, or offer
additional incentives such as upgrades to the facility. They may be able to realize synergies or operate
the facility in as part of a cluster, which would allow them to charge higher parking tariffs. We also
may underestimate our cost to run a new facility, or we may overestimate the amount of volume that a
new facility will generate, and our bid may contemplate rental or operating costs that are too high for
the applicable facility to support. In such a case a facility may turn out to be unprofitable because we
are paying too much in rent or are generating too little in management fees. In such a situation, that
facility will negatively impact our margins and EBITDA.

In addition, certain landlords, including municipalities, may choose not to retender a car park once it
has expired, but rather in-source and operate the car parks themselves. This decision on the part of the
landlord can result in a loss of revenue or the loss of opportunity to tender for a competitor’s former
lease and increased competition for other car parks. As a result of such competition we may not be able
to win new tenders or renew tenders on commercially favorable terms or at all, which could have a
material adverse effect on our business, results of operations or financial condition.

**_Tenders may be subject to modification or interpretation by the granting party and awards of tenders_**
**_may be challenged by third parties._**

The municipalities and large companies who award parking tenders are entitled to interpret the tender
contract, resolve any doubt regarding execution, modify it for reason of public interest, terminate it
early and determine the effects of such termination. The awarding party may contractually modify a
tender agreement for public interest reasons that may affect the terms of the service provision or the
price of tariffs paid by users. Additionally, unsuccessful bidders may challenge the decision of an
awarding authority before the courts. Any decision adopted by a granting authority with respect to a
competitive bidding process may be challenged be a third party provided this party has a legitimate
interest in the result of the annulment of such decision. There can be no assurance that our right to
contracts we have won through a competitive bidding process will be upheld. The modification of such
agreements by the granting authority, delays caused by claims brought by unsuccessful bidders and
cancellation or rescission by a court of our tender agreements could have significant adverse effects on
our business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_Our lease contracts and management contracts have limited durations and are subject to termination_**
**_by the contracting counterparty under the various terms and conditions._**

Our leases and management contracts are typically long-term arrangements with an average remaining
life for our top 100 contracts (based on weighted average Pre-IFRS 16 Contract Contribution for the
year ended December 31, 2019) of approximately 12 years. Of our top 20 contracts by Pre-IFRS 16
Contract Contribution, only four are up for renewal by the end of 2026, representing approximately
3.9% of our Pre-IFRS 16 Contract Contribution for the year ended December 31, 2019. There may be
significant competition to renew existing leases or management contracts. This risk is more pronounced
where the contract is with a public authority and where a bidding process is required as opposed to with
a private landlord where we can initiate bilateral discussions ahead of upcoming lease expirations.
Approximately 33% of our revenue in 2019 was with public or quasi-public authorities versus with
private landlords. The loss of, or the renewal on less commercially favorable terms of, a significant
number of our existing facilities, or one or more of our largest facilities, could materially adversely
affect our business, results of operations or financial condition.

We are also subject to the termination rights set forth in the terms and conditions in our agreements.
For example, in some of our contracts, a change in our shareholders may trigger the counterparty’s right
to terminate the lease or management contract. A counterparty may also seek to terminate if we are not
meeting our contractual requirements under the contract, such as maintenance obligations. The early
termination by the relevant authorities of one or more of our lease or management contracts could
materially adversely affect our business, results of operations or financial condition.

**_If we fail to stay current with developments in technology necessary for our business, our operations_**
**_could be harmed and our ability to compete effectively could be diminished_**

New technologies are changing the current parking market, resulting in an increased focus on
information technology developments. Sophisticated information technology and other systems,
including systems for the efficient collection and management of revenue are integral to our business.
In order to maintain the quality of our operations, we refine, update or replace our information
technology and other systems with more advanced systems on a regular basis.

Motorists increasingly use mobile phone applications and online parking reservation services that allow
them to reserve parking at garages, lots and directly with individual owners. As a result, we constantly
develop new applications and upgrade our information technology to adapt to changing preferences, to
keep up with market demand for new services and to match services offered by our competitors. For
example, in 2018 we also launched our APCOA FLOW system, which is an open, digital and scalable
cloud-based platform which connects most of our parking garages, including parking technology, with
our customers and their vehicles via smartphone apps. This system also provides real time data on
occupancy and availability of our parking facilities. Our competitors may develop more efficient or
popular solutions, which could attract more customers seeking to park their cars and could affect our
business, operations and revenues.

Developing and maintaining our systems will require significant capital. If we are unable to introduce
information technology and other systems as quickly as our competitors our ability to compete
effectively could be diminished. If we are unable to replace outdated or broken systems within budgeted
costs or on schedule, our operations could be harmed. Our operations could also be harmed and our
ability to compete diminished if we are unable to realize the intended benefits of any new information
technology or other systems. Each of these could have a material adverse effect on our business, results
of operations or financial condition. Further, if we fail to keep up with technological advances in our
industry, including advances to maintain or improve our cost-effectiveness or that add value to the
services we can offer to customers, our brand may be diminished which may harm our ability to win
new leases and management contracts.

**_Our information technology systems may fail or be interrupted, which could materially adversely_**
**_affect our business. In addition, cyber-attacks on our information systems and any failure to_**
**_maintain the integrity of customer data could harm our reputation and subject us to costs, fines and_**
**_lawsuits._**

We rely on numerous information technology systems that allow us to monitor and manage our parking
spaces and facilities, control and collect fees, maintain our financial records, manage our employees
and gather information which our management team uses to make decisions regarding our business,
including technical information that is used formulate bids for spaces or contracts. The operation of our
business is increasingly dependent on the use of these systems. As a result, system failures or disruptions
resulting from computer viruses, cyber-attacks, cyber terrorism, security breaches or other causes could
have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations or financial condition.

We also collect and retain large volumes of internal, employee and customer data, including credit card
numbers, license plates and other personally identifiable information during the normal course of
business. Using our various information technology systems, we collect, process, analyze and report
such data. The integrity and protection of our customer, employee and company data is critical to our
business. Our customers and employees expect that we will adequately protect their personal
information and adhere to information security and privacy regulations. These regulations are
increasingly demanding in the jurisdictions where we operate. Theft, loss, fraudulent or unlawful use
of customer, employee or company data could harm our reputation and result in remedial and other
costs, fines and lawsuits, which may be material. See “—We are subject to stringent data privacy laws
_of each jurisdiction in which we operate and may be adversely affected by changes in the laws and_
_regulations of each jurisdiction in which we operate and be exposed to increased compliance costs”_

**_The rates that we can charge our parking customers may be subject to limitations set forth in the_**
**_lease contract or may be limited by law._**

In certain circumstances we may be required to limit the parking tariffs we can charge to customers
based on governmental regulations or contractual limitations. For example, in our contracts with
municipalities or other government entities the maximum tariffs we can charge to our customers are set
by the client and we are not allowed to increase such tariffs above the established limit. These
restrictions may impact our profitability from our operations. If the pricing structures at facilities we
operate restrict us from profitably operating our facilities and we are unable to adjust them due to
contractual or regulatory limitations, we could experience a material decline in the profitability of or a
loss with respect our facilities which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of
operations or financial condition. Moreover, limitations on our ability to increase parking tariffs could
negatively affect our ability to effectively address issues arising from factors that are outside of our
control, such as exposure to inflation and increases in minimum or market wages. Furthermore, our
business may be adversely affected if governments chose to reduce parking fees or introduce free
parking to make certain locations, such as inner cities, more attractive to consumers or to support
essential workers, such as at hospitals.

**_Changes in the legal and regulatory framework for the management and operation of parking_**
**_facilities may impose significant costs on us._**

We must comply with a variety of laws and regulations relating to our leases, some of which impose
substantial financial and other penalties for non-compliance. In addition, we are exposed to the risk of
changes in the regulatory regime, which could potentially impose additional costs on our business or
subject us to more onerous operating requirements, and thus have an adverse impact on our business,
results of operations or financial condition.

**_If our landlords or property owners face financial difficulties, our leases or ability to operate certain_**
**_of our facilities may be adversely affected._**

If our landlords or other persons owning the properties in which our facilities are located experience
financial difficulties, we may be exposed to certain risks such as poor infrastructure in the areas
surrounding and servicing our parking facilities or the closure of stores or other attractions drawing
customers to our facilities, thereby decreasing the demand for those parking spaces. We may be required
to initiate legal proceedings to claim amounts owed under management contracts.

These risks may be exacerbated by the impact of a future economic downturn in Europe and potential
austerity measures imposed by the national governments or by the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic.
If our landlords are unable to effectively address financial difficulties they are facing or become subject
to bankruptcy proceedings, we may be exposed to the risk of closure of our facilities and renegotiation
or loss of our contracts.

Additionally, approximately 33% of 2019 revenue was with municipalities or other public or quasipublic entities. If a municipality with which we have an agreement faces financial difficulties we may
be exposed to certain risks such as poorly maintained infrastructure in the areas surrounding and
servicing the relevant facilities. Furthermore, certain municipalities facing financial challenges may be
reluctant or unwilling to pay compensation amounts to which we are entitled under the relevant
agreements. As a result, we may be required to initiate legal proceedings. This risk would be further
exacerbated by an economic downturn in Europe. If a municipality with whom we have a contract
experiences financial difficulties we are still obliged to continue providing services under our long-term
contracts, regardless of outstanding revenues or compensation owed, which could materially adversely
affect our business, results of operations or financial condition

**_Certain transfers of our leases, including indirect transfers are or may be subject to the prior approval_**
**_of our counterparties to those contracts, and, under certain of our long-term contracts, insolvency_**
**_proceedings or a change of control may result in the termination of the agreement._**

In certain cases, counterparties impose contractual restrictions on transfers of our rights, including
change of control clauses, which prohibit the transfer of our rights without the relevant counterparties’
prior approval. Under the terms of certain of our long-term contracts and/or under applicable law, the
counterparty to the contract may have the right to terminate the agreement in the event that insolvency
or winding-up proceedings are instituted or, upon the occurrence of certain events, if we are in breach
of our obligations under such agreements.

In the event of an enforcement action under the terms of the Notes or the Guarantees that results in the
transfer of ownership of the Issuer or any other Guarantor, or a change in the shareholding of the Issuer
for other reasons, one or more counterparties may argue that an indirect transfer also requires their prior
approval. As such, the counterparty may attempt to cancel our contract if such change of control clauses
exist in the relevant contract and such approval is not sought or granted. In addition, the uncertainty
concerning the transferability of such contracts itself could reduce the value placed on such contracts
by third parties and ultimately reduce the amount recovered in the event of an enforcement action.

**_If we are unable to maintain our reputation as a quality operator, we may be unable to win bids to_**
**_renew our existing contracts or enter into new contracts, and our business, results of operations or_**
**_financial condition may be materially and adversely affected._**

Since our revenue depends on cash flows from operating parking facilities under long-term contracts,
it is important that we maintain good relationships with landlords and property owners in order to bid
for, win and renew contracts. In addition, our reputation as a reliable operator of parking facilities is
important in winning and renewing contracts. We believe the experience of our management, the quality
of our reputation in the key markets in which we operate and the rapport that we maintain with landlords
and property owners differentiates us from our competitors and are important factors for the generation
of new business opportunities that support our growth. However, if we are unable to maintain good
working relationships with the landlords and property owners, or if we do not meet or exceed their
expectations, such parties may be unwilling to maintain or grow their business with us, in which case
our business, results of operations or financial condition may be materially and adversely affected.

**_Our ability to expand our business by leasing new parking facilities will be dependent upon the_**
**_availability and cost of capital._**

We intend to continue to expand our business through organic growth. We typically make certain capital
expenditures at newly leased sites to introduce or upgrade equipment and facilities. Our ability to
expand our business will depend in part upon the availability of adequate capital, which in turn requires
cash flow generated by our business and the availability of debt and equity financing. Any economic
downturn, including as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic may have a negative impact on the
availability of excess cash and the availability and cost of bank financing. If we are unable to obtain the
funds needed on acceptable terms, we will not be able to continue to expand our operations, which
could materially adversely affect our business, results of operations or financial condition.

**_We may not be able to successfully realize our strategy to acquire other parking facility operators._**

The off-street car parking industry in Europe is highly fragmented with a limited number of large
players. Accordingly, market dynamics make it possible for large private players to acquire small
competitors at attractive multiples and as such, we are focused on growing in part through acquisitions.
We expect to continue to evaluate opportunities to acquire businesses that complement our operations.
However, there can be no assurance that any acquisition we make in the future will deliver the
anticipated benefits. In addition, the process of integrating an acquired business may create unforeseen
difficulties, take longer than expected, result in the incurrence of unexpected costs and expenses or we

may not realize the synergies or operational advantages expected. The risks we face in connection with
any potential acquisition of a business include, but are not limited to:

- management time and focus may be diverted from operating our business to acquisition
integration;

- clients or key employees of an acquired business may not remain, which could negatively
impact our ability to grow that acquired business;

- we may face competition from management or key employees of an acquired business in case
of their departure;

- integration of the acquired business’s accounting, information technology, human resources,
and other administrative systems may fail to permit effective management and expense

- implementing internal controls, procedures, and policies appropriate for a public company in
an acquired business that lacked some of these controls, procedures and policies may fail;

- additional indebtedness incurred as a result of an acquisition may impact our financial position,
results of operations, and cash flows; and

- unanticipated or unknown operational, commercial or technical issues or liabilities may arise
relating to the acquired business.

If we fail to identify and enter into attractive markets, to identify and operate facilities on acceptable
terms, to attract, hire and retain skilled staff, to implement the appropriate infrastructure or to raise the
required funds to successfully complete acquisitions, our business plans may be jeopardized and the
intended consolidation or increase of our market share may fail to materialize, which could materially
adversely affect our business, financial condition or results of operations.

**_Instances of theft, fraud, bribery, corruption and privacy breaches involving our management,_**
**_employees, business partners or agents could expose us to penalties and reputational damage and_**
**_could hinder our ability to acquire or renew contracts or even continue our operating activities._**

The decentralized nature of our operations as well as our employees’ access to the cash that we collect
from our operations exposes us to potential theft and other criminal acts. For example, in 2016 one of
our employees in Norway stole approximately €0.5 million in coins from parking meter change drawers
over a period of approximately three years, and in the past we have had similar theft instances in other
jurisdictions. While we have a compliance program and internal policies in place to mitigate the risks
of theft, fraud, bribery, corruption and privacy breaches in the contract tender processes we engage in
and for our business as a whole, we cannot assure that we can detect or prevent every instance of theft,
fraud, bribery, corruption or breaches of privacy involving our employees, business partners or agents.

We may be subject to civil and criminal penalties and to reputational damage as a result of such
incidents. Instances of theft, fraud, bribery, corruption and breaches of privacy may also be taken into
account as a negative factor by public authorities or private companies in evaluating our bids to acquire
or renew contracts. Such incidents could result in a prohibition to tender for, or could otherwise prevent
us from winning or renewing contracts, or make it more difficult for us to win or renew contracts in the
future. Any involvement or association of our senior management, employees, business partners,
suppliers or agents with theft, fraud, bribery, corruption and breaches of privacy, or allegations or
rumors relating thereto, could negatively impact our reputation and materially adversely affect our
business, results of operations or financial condition. For example, in 2018 we lost an on-street tender
in Antwerp, Belgium, due to reputational issues resulting from a former fraud case in that city that was
first identified in 2016, where one of our former technical directors was found guilty of large scale theft
after we uncovered that he had stolen approximately €5 million in coins from parking meter change
drawers over a period of at least five years, and in the past we had similar, albeit smaller, case of theft
in other jurisdictions. As a result of this case, we hired third party advisors to assist us with identifying
areas of risk. We have implemented several measures in order to prevent similar cases from occurring

##### 47


-----

in the future that we deem adequate and we continuously review and upgrade our compliance policies.
We also have a dedicated internal audit and compliance team in place. However, we cannot guarantee
that these measures will be effective in reducing such cases from happening in the future or at all. In
addition, we have in place a whistleblower program, through which we have in the past received, and
we may in the future receive, allegations of compliance breaches by our employees, such as for fraud,
bribery, political contributions and embezzlement. We have systems in place to thoroughly investigate
such allegations, and although to date (and except as noted above) our investigations have resulted in
such allegations being dismissed or not being found material, there can be no assurance that our
investigations were sufficient or that future allegations will not result in compliance breaches in the
future. Any actual or alleged compliance breaches could result in adverse publicity and/or have material
adverse effects on our business or results of operations.

**_In the auditor’s report on our 2019 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements there was attention_**
**_drawn to uncertainty on the future and the impact that could have on continuing as a going concern._**

The auditor’s report on our 2019 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements, issued by
PricewaterhouseCoopers GmbH Wirtschaftsprüfungsgesellschaft, our independent auditors, contains
an emphasis of matter paragraph on the material uncertainty related to the ability of the Group to
continue as a going concern. This paragraph draws attention to note “43 Group Risk Management—
Going Concern” of the notes to our 2019 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements, where the
executive directors describe that in connection with the ongoing effects of the COVID-19 pandemic the
Group’s ability to continue as a going concern depends on the timing of the recovery of the business
and hence, the achievement of the Group’s forecast earnings and cash flows, and respectively, the
continuing financial support of the shareholders and the core banks. As stated in the note “43 Group
Risk Management—Going Concern” in the notes to our 2019 Audited Consolidated Financial
Statements, these events and conditions indicate along with other matters stated there that a material
uncertainty exists that may cast significant doubt on the Group’s ability to continue as a going concern
and that represents a risk that the Company’s ability to continue as a going concern is threatened
pursuant to section 322 paragraph 2 sentence 3 of the German Commercial Code (Handelsgesetzbuch—
HGB). The audit opinion on the 2019 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements is not modified in
respect of this matter. None of our financial information included in this Offering Memorandum,
including our 2019 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements, include any adjustments that may result
from this uncertainty. The auditor’s report on our 2020 Audited Financial Statements does not contain
an emphasis of matter paragraph, as the various measures taken by the Group to counteract the impact
of the COVID-19 pandemic on our results of operations were deemed sufficient to ensure the Group’s
status as a going concern, secure capital and liquidity by providers of equity and debt capital and to
safeguard against further negative developments from the COVID-19 pandemic. However, the COVID19 pandemic has had and continues to have a substantial impact on our business, primarily due to a
significant reduction in volume of traffic at our car parks as a result of the restrictions on movement
and other social distancing measures imposed by governments in Europe in response to the COVID-19
pandemic. See “Risks Related to our Business and Industry—The effects of the outbreak of COVID-19
_have disrupted our operations, which have had and may continue to have a negative adverse effect on_
_our business, results of operations, financial condition and prospects.” Our ability to forecast our pace_
of recovery from the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic, the eventual levels to which our results of
operations will return as well as our cash flows are dependent on when and the extent to which we can
return to our pre-pandemic operating levels. Although our 2020 Audited Financial Statements do not
contain an emphasis of matter paragraph, if one or more of the assumptions in making our assessment
to report as a going concern are found to be incorrect, we may be unable to continue as a going concern.
If we are unable to continue as a going concern, we would have to liquidate our assets and may receive
less that the value at which those assets are carried on our 2020 Audited Consolidated Financial
Statements, and investors could lose a part or all of their investment in the Notes.
