**_The Issuer and the Guarantors will have control over the Collateral securing the Notes, and the sale_**
**_of particular assets could reduce the pool of assets securing the Notes._**

The Security Documents will allow the Issuer and the Guarantors to remain in possession of, retain
exclusive control over, freely operate and collect, invest and dispose of any income from the Collateral
securing the Notes. So long as no default or event of default under the Indenture would result therefrom,
the Issuer and the Guarantors may, among other things, without any release or consent by the Security
Agent, conduct ordinary course activities with respect to the Collateral, such as selling, factoring,
abandoning or otherwise disposing of the Collateral and making ordinary course cash payments,
including repayments of indebtedness.

With respect to Collateral located in Sweden and Denmark, the above means that security created over
such Collateral is unperfected. To the extent such security remains unperfected, the delay in perfection
creates a clawback risk.

**_There are circumstances other than the repayment or discharge of Notes under which the Collateral_**
**_securing the Notes and the Note Guarantees will be released automatically and under which the Note_**
**_Guarantees will be released automatically, without your consent or the consent of the Trustee._**

Under various circumstances, the Note Guarantees and the Collateral securing the Notes will be released
automatically. See “Description of the Notes—Note Guarantees” and “Description of the Notes—
_Security—Release of Liens.” In addition, if the Security Agent sells Collateral comprising the shares of_
any of our subsidiaries as a result of an enforcement action in accordance with the Intercreditor
Agreement, then claims under the Notes and the Note Guarantees may be released or transferred. See
“Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement” and “Description of the
_Notes—Security—Release of Liens.” Your ability to recover on the Notes could be materially impaired_
in such circumstances.

The Intercreditor Agreement also provides that the Collateral securing the Notes may be released and
retaken in connection with the refinancing of certain indebtedness, including the Notes, if the Issuer has
confirmed in writing to the Security Agent that it has determined that it is neither possible nor desirable
to implement any such refinancing on terms satisfactory to it by instead granting additional Collateral
and/or amending the terms of the existing Collateral. Such a release and retaking of Collateral may give
rise to the start of a new “hardening period” in respect of such Collateral. Under certain circumstances,
other creditors, insolvency administrators or representatives or courts could challenge the validity and
enforceability of the grant of such Collateral. Any such challenge, if successful, could potentially limit
your recovery in respect of such Collateral and thus reduce your recovery under the Notes.

-----

Furthermore, under German law a secured party is, upon request by the relevant security grantor,
obligated to release security if the realizable value of the security is significantly higher than the value
of the obligations secured by such security. Finally, if the secured obligations are discharged,
exchanged, novated or terminated, a pledge or other accessory security interest created pursuant to a
Security Document governed by German law might be released as a matter of German law.

Furthermore, any security created over any Collateral by or pursuant to a Security Document governed
by Swedish law is likely not valid and enforceable under Swedish law to the extent it could be released,
including in connection with a transaction that is permitted, pre-agreed or similar, (including, but not
limited to, any release, amalgamation, merger, consolidation, dissolution, re-designation, disposal,
reorganization or reduction of capital) without the prior written consent (in its sole discretion on a caseby-case basis) of the Security Agent, other than following full discharge of the obligations secured by
the relevant Security Document.

**_The Notes will be structurally subordinated to the liabilities of the Issuer’s non-Guarantor_**
**_subsidiaries._**

Some, but not all, of the Subsidiaries of the Issuer will guarantee the Notes. The Issuer’s subsidiaries
that are Guarantors held 56% of the total unconsolidated assets of the Group (on a Pre-IFRS 16 basis)
as of December 31, 2019, and generated 83% of the total unconsolidated net sales revenues and 81% of
the total unconsolidated Pre-IFRS 16 Adjusted EBITDA of the Group for the year ended December 31,
2019, in each case, before intercompany eliminations. In addition, as of March 31, 2021, our
subsidiaries that will not guarantee the Notes had €1.5 million of outstanding third-party debt that would
have ranked structurally senior to the obligations of the Issuer and the Guarantors under the Notes and
the Note Guarantees. Unless a subsidiary of the Issuer is a Guarantor, such subsidiary will not have any
obligations to pay amounts due under the Notes or to make funds available for that purpose. The
Indenture will, subject to some limitations, permit our non-Guarantor subsidiaries to incur substantial
amounts of additional indebtedness and will not restrict the amount of other liabilities that may be
incurred by these subsidiaries. Generally, holders of indebtedness of, and trade creditors of, nonGuarantor companies, including lenders under bank financing agreements, are entitled to payments of
their claims from the assets of such non-Guarantor companies before these assets are made available
for distribution to the Issuer or any Guarantor, as a direct or indirect shareholder.

Accordingly, in the event that any non-Guarantor company becomes insolvent, is liquidated,
reorganized or dissolved or is otherwise wound up other than as part of a solvent transaction:

- the creditors of the Issuer (including the holders of the Notes) and the Guarantors will have no
right to proceed against the assets of such company; and

- the creditors of such non-Guarantor company, including trade creditors, will generally be
entitled to payment in full from the sale or other disposal of the assets of such company before
any Guarantor, as a direct or indirect shareholder, will be entitled to receive any distributions
from such subsidiary.

As such, the Notes and each Note Guarantee will be structurally subordinated to the creditors (including
trade creditors) and any preferred stockholders of our non-Guarantor subsidiaries.

**_Each Note Guarantee and security may be subject to certain limitations on enforcement and may be_**
**_limited by applicable laws or subject to certain defenses that may limit its validity and enforceability._**

Each Note Guarantee provides the holders of the Notes with a direct claim against the relevant
Guarantor. However, the Indenture will provide that each Note Guarantee will be limited to the
maximum amount that can be guaranteed by the relevant Guarantor without rendering the relevant Note
Guarantee, as it relates to that Guarantor, voidable or otherwise ineffective or limited under applicable
law, and enforcement of each Note Guarantee would be subject to certain generally available defenses.
In addition, the Indenture will provide for further limitations in accordance with the specific legal
requirements in each Guarantor jurisdiction. For example, the Note Guarantees and security interests to
be granted by each Italian Guarantor will only guarantee and secure the Issuer’s obligations under
Tranche B (as defined herein) of the Notes. See “Certain Insolvency Law Considerations and
_Limitations on the Validity and Enforceability of the Note Guarantees and Security Interests.” The same_
limitations may apply to security interests (other than the Note Guarantees) that will be provided by the
Guarantors in certain jurisdictions.

##### 68


-----

Enforcement of any of the Note Guarantees or security against any Guarantor will be subject to certain
defenses and limitations available to Guarantors in the relevant jurisdiction. These laws and defenses
generally include those that relate to corporate purpose or benefit, fraudulent conveyance or transfer,
voidable preference, insolvency or bankruptcy challenges, financial assistance, the preservation of share
capital, thin capitalization, capital maintenance or similar laws, regulations or defenses affecting the
rights of creditors generally. If one or more of these laws, defenses and limitations are applicable, a
Guarantor may have no liability or decreased liability under its Note Guarantee or other security
depending on the amounts of its other obligations and applicable law. Limitations on the enforceability
of judgments obtained in New York courts in such jurisdictions could limit the enforceability of any
Note Guarantee against any Guarantor.

Although laws differ among various jurisdictions, in general, under bankruptcy or insolvency law and
other laws, a court could (i) void or invalidate all or a portion of a Guarantor’s obligations under its
Note Guarantee, direct that the holders of the Notes return any amounts paid under a Note Guarantee to
the relevant Guarantor or to a fund for the benefit of the Guarantor’s creditors or (ii) take other action
that is detrimental to you, typically if the court found, among other things, that:

- the relevant Note Guarantee or security interest in the Collateral was incurred with actual intent
to give preference to one creditor over another, to hinder, delay or defraud creditors or
shareholders of the Guarantor; or, in certain jurisdictions, when the granting of the Note
Guarantees has the effect of giving a creditor a preference or when the recipient was aware that
the Guarantor was insolvent when it granted the relevant Note Guarantee or security interest;

- the Guarantor or security provider did not receive fair consideration or reasonably equivalent
value or corporate benefit for the relevant Note Guarantee and the Guarantor: (i) was insolvent
or rendered insolvent because of the relevant Note Guarantee or security interest; (ii) was
undercapitalized or became undercapitalized because of the relevant Note Guarantee; or (iii)
intended to incur, or believed that it would incur, indebtedness beyond its ability to pay at
maturity;

- the relevant Note Guarantee and/or Security Documents were held to exceed the corporate
objects of the Guarantor or not to be in the best interests or for the corporate benefit of the
Guarantor;

- the amount paid or payable under the relevant Note Guarantee was in excess of the maximum
amount permitted under applicable law; or

- the grant of the Note Guarantee or security is, having regard to the risk accepted by the holders
of the Notes, on terms which are, or were, such as to require grossly exorbitant payments to be
made (whether conditionally or in certain contingencies) in respect of the subscription for the
Notes or otherwise grossly contravenes ordinary principles of fair dealing.

These or similar laws may also apply to any future Note Guarantee granted by any of our subsidiaries
pursuant to the Indenture or other securities pursuant to the Security Documents.

We cannot assure you which standard a court would apply in determining whether a Guarantor was
“insolvent” at the relevant time or that, regardless of the method of the valuation, a court would not
determine that a Guarantor was insolvent on that date, or that a court would not determine, regardless
of whether or not a Guarantor was insolvent on the date its Note Guarantee was issued, that payments
to holders of the Notes constituted preferences, fraudulent transfers or conveyances on other grounds.
The measure of insolvency for purposes of fraudulent transfer laws vary depending upon applicable
governing law. Generally, an entity would be considered insolvent if, at the time it incurred
indebtedness: the sum of its debts, including contingent liabilities, is greater than the fair value of all its
assets; the present fair saleable value of its assets is less than the amount required to pay the probable
liability on its existing debts and liabilities, including contingent liabilities, as they become due; or it
cannot pay its debts as they become due.

will apply in making a determination of the maximum liability of each Guarantor, or the effectiveness

in which case the entire liability may be extinguished. If a court decided that a Note Guarantee was a

**_We may not be able to obtain the funds required to repurchase the Notes upon a Change of Control_**
**_and the occurrence of certain important corporate events will not constitute a Change of Control._**

The Indenture will contain provisions relating to certain events constituting a “Change of Control” (as
defined in “Description of the Notes”). Upon the occurrence of a Change of Control, we will be required
to offer to repurchase all outstanding Notes at a price equal to 101% of their principal amount, plus
accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the date of repurchase. If a Change of
Control were to occur, we cannot assure you that we would have sufficient funds available at such time,
or that we would have sufficient funds to provide to the Issuer to pay the purchase price of the
outstanding Notes or that the restrictions in the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement, the
Indenture, the Intercreditor Agreement or our other then-existing contractual obligations would allow
us to make such required repurchases. A Change of Control may trigger a mandatory prepayment of
amounts outstanding under the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement and other indebtedness even
if such event is deemed not to be a change of control under the Indenture. The repurchase of the Notes
pursuant to such an offer could cause a default under such indebtedness, even if the Change of Control
itself does not. The ability of the Issuer to receive cash from its subsidiaries to allow it to pay cash to
the holders of the Notes following the occurrence of a Change of Control, may be limited by our thenexisting financial resources. Sufficient funds may not be available when necessary to make any required
repurchases. If an event constituting a Change of Control were to occur at a time when we are prohibited
from providing funds to the Issuer for the purpose of repurchasing the Notes, we may seek the consent
of the lenders under such indebtedness to the purchase of the Notes or may attempt to refinance the
borrowings that contain such prohibition. If such a consent to repay such borrowings is not obtained,
the Issuer would remain prohibited from repurchasing any Notes. In addition, we expect that we would
require third-party financing to make an offer to repurchase the Notes upon a Change of Control. We
cannot assure you that we would be able to obtain such financing. Any failure by the Issuer to offer to
purchase the Notes would constitute a default under the Indenture, which would, in turn, constitute a
default under the New Revolving Credit Facility. See “Description of the Notes—Change of Control.”

The Change of Control provision that will be contained in the Indenture may not necessarily afford you
protection in the event of certain important corporate events, including a reorganization, restructuring,
merger or other similar transaction involving us that may adversely affect you, because such corporate
events may not involve a shift in voting power or beneficial ownership or, even if they do, may not
constitute a Change of Control as defined in the Indenture. Except as described under “Description of
_the Notes—Change of Control,” the Indenture will not contain provisions that would require the Issuer_
to offer to repurchase or redeem the Notes in the event of a reorganization, restructuring, merger,
recapitalization or similar transaction.

Moreover, as a matter of German law, with regard to any Change of Control triggered by measures
taken in respect of the Issuer for the purpose of a debt/equity-swap as part of an insolvency plan
proceeding (Insolvenzplanverfahren) or a restructuring plan proceeding
(Restrukturierungsplanverfahren) under German law, the Change of Control provision could be deemed
void and we would not be required to offer the repurchase of the outstanding Notes.

In addition, the occurrence of certain events that might otherwise constitute a Change of Control will
be deemed not to be a Change of Control if a certain net consolidated leverage ratio calculated in
accordance with the “Description of the Notes” is not exceeded in connection with such an event. In
this case, holders of Notes would not be entitled to require the Issuer to repurchase their Notes and

might be lower than the 101% change of control repurchase price. See “Description of the Notes—
_Change of Control” and “Description of the Notes—Certain Definitions—Change of Control Triggering_
_Event.”_

The definition of Change of Control in the Indenture will include a disposition of all or substantially all
of the assets of the Issuer and its restricted subsidiaries (if any), taken as a whole, to certain persons.
Although there is a limited body of case law interpreting the phrase “all or substantially all,” there is no
precise established definition of the phrase under applicable law. Accordingly, in certain circumstances,
there may be a degree of uncertainty as to whether a particular transaction would involve a disposition
of “all or substantially all” of the Issuer’s assets and its restricted subsidiaries taken as a whole. As a
result, it may be unclear as to whether a Change of Control has occurred and whether the Issuer is
required to make an offer to repurchase the relevant Notes.

**_The Notes will initially be held in book-entry form, and therefore you must rely on the procedures of_**
**_the relevant clearing systems to exercise any rights and remedies._**

Owners of the book-entry interests will not be considered owners or holders of relevant Notes unless
and until definitive notes are issued in exchange for book-entry interests. Instead, the common
depositary (or its nominee) for Euroclear and Clearstream will be the sole registered holder of the Notes
in global form.

Payments of principal, interest and other amounts owing on or in respect of the Notes in global form
will be made to the Paying Agent, which will make payments to Euroclear and Clearstream. Thereafter,
such payments will be credited to Euroclear and Clearstream participants’ accounts that hold bookentry interests in the Notes in global form and credited by such participants to indirect participants.
After payment to Euroclear and Clearstream, none of the Issuer, the Guarantors, the Trustee, the
Transfer Agent, the Paying Agent, the Calculation Agent or the Registrar will have any responsibility
or liability for any aspect of the records relating to or payments of interest, principal or other amounts
to Euroclear and Clearstream, or to owners of book-entry interests. Accordingly, if you own a bookentry interest in the Notes, you must rely on the procedures of Euroclear and Clearstream and, if you
are not a participant in Euroclear and/or Clearstream, on the procedures of the participant through which
you own your interest, to exercise any rights and obligations of a holder of the Notes under the
Indenture.

Owners of book-entry interests will not have the direct right to act upon our solicitations for consents
or requests for waivers or other actions from holders of the Notes, including the enforcement of security
for the Notes and the Note Guarantees. Instead, if you own a book-entry interest, you will be permitted
to act directly only to the extent you have received appropriate proxies to do so from Euroclear and
Clearstream or, if applicable, from a participant. We cannot assure you that procedures implemented
for the granting of such proxies will be sufficient to enable you to vote on any requested actions or to
take any other action on a timely basis.

Similarly, upon the occurrence of an event of default under the Indenture, unless and until the relevant
Definitive Registered Notes (as defined in “Book-Entry, Delivery and Form”) are issued in respect of

**_There may not be an active trading market for the Notes, in which case your ability to sell the Notes_**

We cannot assure you as to:

- the liquidity of any market in the Notes;

- your ability to sell your Notes; or

Future trading prices for the Notes will depend on many factors, including, among other things,
prevailing interest rates, our operating results and the market for similar securities. Historically, the
market for non-investment-grade securities has been subject to disruptions that have caused substantial
volatility in the prices of securities similar to the Notes. The liquidity of a trading market for the Notes
may be adversely affected by a general decline in the market for similar securities and is subject to
disruptions that may cause volatility in prices. The trading market for the Notes may attract different
investors and this may affect the extent to which the Notes may trade. It is possible that the market for
the Notes will be subject to disruptions. Any such disruption may have a negative effect on you, as a
holder of the Notes, regardless of our prospects and financial performance. As a result, there can be no
assurance that there will be an active trading market for the Notes. If no active trading market develops,
you may not be able to resell your holding of the Notes at a fair value, if at all.

alternative admission to listing on another stock exchange) of the Notes from the Official List of the

**_Credit ratings may not reflect all risks, are not recommendations to buy or hold securities and may_**
**_be subject to revision, suspension or withdrawal at any time._**

One or more independent credit rating agencies may assign credit ratings to the Notes. The credit ratings
address our ability to perform our obligations under the terms of the Notes and credit risks in
determining the likelihood that payments will be made when due under the Notes. The ratings may not
reflect the potential impact of all risks related to the structure, market, additional risk factors discussed
above and other factors that may affect the value of the Notes. A credit rating is not a recommendation
to buy, sell or hold securities and may be subject to revision, suspension or withdrawal by the rating
agency at any time. No assurance can be given that a credit rating will remain constant for any given
period of time or that a credit rating will not be lowered or withdrawn entirely by the credit rating
agency if, in its judgment, circumstances in the future so warrant. A suspension, reduction or withdrawal
at any time of the credit rating assigned to the relevant Notes by one or more of the credit rating agencies
may adversely affect the cost, terms and conditions of our financings, could adversely affect the value
and trading of the Notes and have an adverse impact on our cost of capital in our local business and our
ability to secure local financing or win additional contracts.

**_The transferability of the Notes may be limited under applicable securities laws._**

The Notes and the Note Guarantees have not been, and will not be, registered under the Securities Act

**_The Sponsor may have interests that do not align with yours._**

The Sponsor has the power to control our affairs and policies. The Sponsor also controls, to a large

The Sponsor may also have an interest in pursuing dividend payments, acquisitions, divestitures,

**_You may face foreign currency exchange risks as a result of investing in the Notes._**

The Notes will be denominated and payable in euro. If you are a U.S. investor, an investment in the
Notes will entail foreign exchange related risks due to, among other factors, possible significant changes
in the value of the euro relative to the U.S. dollar because of economic, political and other factors over
which we have no control. Depreciation of the euro against the U.S. dollar could cause a decrease in
the effective yield of the Notes below their stated coupon rates and could result in a loss to you on a
U.S. dollar basis.

**_The Notes may be issued with original issue discount for U.S. federal income tax purposes._**

If the stated principal amount of the Notes exceeds their issue price by an amount equal to or greater
than a statutorily defined de minimis amount, then the Notes will be considered to be issued with original
issue discount (“OID”) for U.S. federal income tax purposes. If the Notes are issued with OID, then, in
addition to the stated interest on the Notes, a holder subject to U.S. federal income taxation generally
will be required to include the OID on such Note in gross income (as ordinary income) as it accrues on
a constant yield to maturity basis for U.S. federal income tax purposes, in advance of the receipt of the
cash payments to which such OID is attributable and regardless of the U.S. Holder’s regular method of
accounting for U.S. federal income tax purposes. See “Certain Tax Considerations—Certain U.S.
_Federal Income Tax Considerations—Original Issue Discount.” Prospective investors should consult_
with their tax advisors regarding the application of such rules to the Notes.

**_Upon an IPO Debt Pushdown, material Collateral and Note Guarantees may be released, any retaken_**
**_Collateral may be subject to hardening periods, and holders of the Notes may have adverse tax_**
**_consequences._**

Under certain circumstances, we may undertake the transactions described in “Description of Certain
_Financing_ _Arrangements—Intercreditor_ _Agreement—Provisions_ _Following_ _an IPO” (such_
transactions, an “IPO Debt Pushdown”), pursuant to which the Issuers are entitled to give notice that
will automatically operate so that, among other things, the references in the Indentures and any
Intercreditor Agreement to such Issuer and Restricted Subsidiaries shall apply only to the IPO
Pushdown Entity and its Restricted Subsidiaries. In such event, each holding or parent company of the
IPO Pushdown Entity would be released from its obligations under the applicable Debt Documents,
which would include the release of Note Guarantees and Collateral provided by such entities. There are
no restrictions on the transfer of assets to such entities, and any such release may materially reduce the
Collateral securing the Notes. Moreover, we may elect to, but are not under any obligation to, revoke
or otherwise reverse an IPO Debt Pushdown undertaken in anticipation of an initial public offering, or
to replace any Note Guarantees or Collateral released pursuant thereto, in the event such initial public
offering is not consummated. To the extent that new security documents in respect of any Collateral to
be retaken (including a pledge over the shares of the Issuer) are entered into, such Collateral may be
subject to new hardening periods. In addition, such modifications to the terms of the Notes could be
treated for U.S. federal income tax purposes as a deemed exchange of (i) the Notes as in place prior to
such modifications for (ii) new Notes as in place after such modifications. If such modifications result
in a deemed exchange for U.S. federal income tax purposes, such deemed exchange generally would be
treated as a taxable transaction for U.S. federal income tax purposes in which beneficial owners of the
Notes would be required to recognize any gain or loss. Furthermore, for U.S. federal income tax
purposes, the new Notes deemed issued in such a deemed exchange could be treated as issued with
original issue discount. In such event, holders subject to U.S. federal income taxation would be required
to include the original issue discount in their income as it accrues, in advance of the receipt of cash
corresponding to such income. In addition, the determination of whether the deemed new Notes are
treated as “contingent payment debt instruments” as a result of the possibility of additional payments,
as further described above under “ —Additional Payments,” would be made at the time of the
modification. Holders subject to U.S. federal income taxation should consult their own tax advisors as
to the U.S. federal income tax considerations relating to potential modifications of the Notes in
connection with the IPO Debt Pushdown. It is also possible that the IPO Debt Pushdown could result
in a taxable event for tax purposes other than U.S. federal income tax purposes.

**_Interest paid on a Note paid to a resident of a “non-cooperative jurisdiction” after December 31,_**
**_2021 may be subject to a new German withholding tax, and the Issuer will not be obligated to pay_**
**_any additional amounts in respect of any such withholding._**

Germany recently enacted a new withholding tax at a rate of 15.825% on interest paid by a payor that
is tax resident in Germany to a payee that is tax resident in a “non-cooperative jurisdiction” listed in a
decree to be published by the German Federal Ministry of Finance. The list of non-cooperative

##### 74


-----

jurisdictions, which is expected to be based on the European Union’s list of non-cooperative
jurisdictions and may be amended from time to time, is currently expected to include: American Samoa,
Anguilla, Dominica, Fiji, Guam, Palau, Panama, Samoa, Seychelles, Trinidad and Tobago, the U.S.
Virgin Islands and Vanuatu. The new withholding tax is expected to apply to interest paid after
December 31, 2021 or, in the case of jurisdictions that were added to the European Union’s list of noncooperative jurisdictions after December 31, 2020, to interest paid after December 31, 2022.

If the foregoing withholding tax applies to any amounts payable to a holder of Notes, the Issuer will not
be obligated to pay any additional amounts in respect of such withholding.

Prospective investors should consult their tax advisors regarding the new German withholding tax.

**Overview**

We are a leading parking infrastructure operator and services provider in the European market, with a
large and diversified portfolio of leased and managed parking facilities across 13 European countries.
We operate off-street parking facilities under leases from private and public landlords, and also operate
on- and off-street parking facilities for clients under management contracts. As of March 31, 2021, we
operated approximately 11,700 parking facilities with over 1.6 million parking spaces. We believe we
are either the leading or number two parking facility operator by number of parking spaces in each of
our ten largest country markets.

We benefit from a large, structurally attractive and growing parking market that we believe will benefit
from ongoing outsourcing, mobility and other industry trends such as growth in the number of vehicles
in Europe, urban areas, electric vehicle (“EV”) charging, car hiring and sharing and more recently use
of the car parks as infrastructure for the e-commerce value chain and customer delivery. During 2018,
the European parking market generated approximately €28 to 29 billion in revenues of which
approximately €11 to 12 billion was spent on outsourcing parking management. We believe we are well
positioned to capture the benefits from these trends and the general economic recovery from the
COVID-19 pandemic expected in 2021 and 2022 because we create significant, stable and recurring
value for our clients, for whom parking facilities are often a non-core operation, by providing a large
scale platform that is focused on driving higher revenues by increasing volume, pricing and utilization,
at a lower cost of operation.

##### 78


-----

Our operations benefit from a diverse portfolio of lease and management contracts as well as
geographical, business sector and customer diversification, which made our business more resilient
during the COVID-19 pandemic, while at the same time allowing us to leverage operational similarities
to benefit from scale economies. Our parking facilities are spread across most of Europe (with certain
clusters for operational efficiency) and apart from one large market (Germany), five other countries
(Denmark, Italy, Sweden, the United Kingdom and Norway) each contributed approximately 10% of
our Pre-IFRS 16 Contract Contribution in the year ended December 31, 2019. We operate in a wide
range of business sectors, such as city and shopping, travel, healthcare & education, events and
hospitality, and parking enforcement, with limited correlation between them. Furthermore, many of our
parking facilities are not dedicated to a single institution, business or purpose but are instead multifunctional and used by motorists that visit a variety of locations, whether it is for work, shopping,
restaurant or cultural activities, or other purposes. We have very low contract concentration, with over
5,900 contracts across over 11,700 parking facilities.

**Our Sectors and Geographies**

**_Our Sectors_**

We are a leading, pan-European provider of parking management services, parking enforcement
services and ancillary services across all parking sectors. Our parking sectors include (i) City &
Shopping, (ii) Travel, (iii) Healthcare & Education, (iv) Events & Hospitality and (v) Parking
Enforcement, which include our Park & Control (PAC), Park & Guard and “On-Street” parking
enforcement services.

_City & Shopping_

Our City & Shopping sector has historically been our largest sector in terms of revenue. Within the City
& Shopping sector, our operations include a mixture of lease contracts and management contracts with
clients including municipalities, investors and owners and operators of city centre parking facilities
which are generally visited by consumers for a variety of purposes such as offices, other places of work,
leisure and recreational locations. Short-term parking, including for work, shopping, cultural activities
or other purposes, contributes the majority of revenue by fee type with approximately 65% on average.
Our operations in this sector benefit from ongoing urbanization across Europe as well as the continuing
increase in population mobility, which have historically led to increased vehicle numbers within urban
environments. Our growth in this sector is partially offset by the expanding use of public transportation
as well as the growing popularity of e-commerce, all of which reduces footfall in inner cities. In
addition, we also operate a number of facilities related to either in-town or out-of-town shopping centers
under a mixture of both lease and management contracts. Growth in this sector is generally through a
combination of pricing and through utilizing technology to reduce the costs of operating these facilities
(e.g., through the introduction of ANPR technology).

##### 79


-----

Our results of operations in the City & Shopping sector were significantly affected as a result of the
COVID-19 pandemic, which resulted in the implementation of nationwide lockdowns, increased home
working and the closure of non-essential shops across Europe. Given the quick and almost instant
recovery of the City & Shopping sector upon lifting of lockdown measures during 2020, we expect our
operation in this sector to gradually return to the levels seen before the pandemic as the vaccine roll-out
accelerates and restrictions on social contact are eased across Europe and, particularly in the initial
periods of the recovery, where we expect some consumers switch to using private rather than public
transport.

_Travel_

The Travel sector is our second-largest sector in terms of revenue. Our operations in the Travel sector
include a mixture of lease contracts and management contracts. In the latter, we receive management
fees independently of parking volumes at the underlying parking facility, across a number of segments
of the travel market including airports, train stations and park & ride facilities. Our financial
performance in this sector has historically been partly driven by positive passenger volume trends in
European air travel, which increased by 30% between 2014 and 2019, as well as by increasing
disposable income, which has resulted in an increase in holiday travel. While our performance in the
Travel sector in the three months ended March 31, 2021 and the year ended December 31, 2020, was
significantly affected by the COVID-19 pandemic, which led to a year-on-year decrease in air passenger
numbers across the European Union by 70%, passenger volumes are forecast to recover to their preCOVID-19 pandemic levels by 2024. Despite the volume impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, our
Contract Contribution decreased only by 39% in the year ended December 31, 2020 compared to the
year ended December 31, 2019 due to a combination of our mix of contract types and operations across
different segments of the Travel sector as well as support from our clients. A number of our clients in
this sector waived any guaranteed minimum rents in our airport lease contracts (thereby making them
fully variable rents and thus providing downside protection in the face of reduced travel volumes
throughout the pandemic) and, in a number of locations, our landlords agreed to temporarily reduce the
variable rent percentages.

_Healthcare & Education_

Our operations in the Healthcare & Education sector have historically benefitted from the ongoing
outsourcing of parking management and parking enforcement services by public and private hospital
operators and universities. Our clients in the Healthcare & Education sector include public and private
hospitals as well as universities. Many clients in this sector consider parking to be important as both a
service to offer their visitors in addition to a revenue generator for them. As such, we operate a mixture
of both lease and management contracts, depending on the client’s requirements and our view of the
risk profile of a contract. The healthcare sites are usually characterized by limited available spaces with
different publics to be served: staff, patients and visitors. The efficient management of these customers
flows increasingly requires digital technology. Similarly, in the Education sector there is a mix of
teaching and other staff, students and visitors, again with limited spaces that require careful
management. Particularly in the Healthcare sector we increasingly help the hospitals to expand parking
capacity by planning and coordinating the building of new facilities which we then manage through
contracts with a duration of over 15 years. The Healthcare & Education sector were comparatively less
impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic as hospitals and other healthcare facilities remained opened
throughout the year and continued to benefit from high utilization of parking facilities by, for example,
hospital staff.

_Events and Hospitality_

The Events & Hospitality sector primarily encompasses parking facilities at exhibitions, events
(including sports and cultural venues) and hotels, with both lease and management contracts. Our lease
revenue in particular in this sector will be dependent on the number of events held at these locations or
the number of visitors. Since parking revenues in this sector are highly dependent on the number of

##### 80


-----

events held or visitors to these locations, our contract and rent structures reflect the characteristics of
each location. We usually provide the following services: site-specific ad hoc resources, organize the
car flow, provide the parking equipment and focus on driving revenue which is increasingly pre-booked.
In the three months ended March 31, 2021 and the year ended December 31, 2020, our performance in
the Events and Hospitality sector was significantly affected by the COVID-19 pandemic, which led to
the cancellation of mass events and the temporary closure of trade fairs and entertainment venues and
significantly reduced occupancy at hotels.

_Parking Enforcement Services_

Parking enforcement services sales revenue comprises control fees and revenue generated from
enforcement of parking on behalf of the owner or landlord of the parking facilities. This is generally
generated by our parking attendants issuing the control fees to owners of vehicles who have parked in
contravention of the parking regulations at the site, or through the use of technology such as ANPR
cameras. See “—Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations—Fee Type—Control Fees.”

**COVID-19 Impact on Our Business**

Our results of operation in the three months ended March 31, 2021 and the year ended December 31,
2020 have been impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic. In 2020, total revenue declined across all fee
types by a total of 26.2%. However, the decline was mainly driven by a reduction of short-term parking
revenue (53% of total revenue 2019) by 42.0%, while revenue from all other fee types in aggregate
decreased by only 8.2%. See “—Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations—Fee Type.”

Following an approximately 16.1% increase in revenue and an 11.1% increase in Pre-IFRS 16 Adjusted
EBITDA in the two months ended February 28, 2020 compared to the prior-year period, revenue
generation and Pre-IFRS 16 Adjusted EBITDA declined sharply, by approximately 44% and 173%,
respectively, in the second quarter of 2020 as a result of the strict lockdown measures imposed by
governments across Europe to slow the spread of COVID-19. The imposition of lockdown measures
had most severe impact on our operations during the period from March to May 2020, when short-term
parking revenues were significantly reduced, as consumers worked from home and were only allowed
or advised to go out for essential or narrowly-defined permitted purposes.

With the easing of lockdown measures across our jurisdictions of operation towards the end of the
second quarter of 2020, consumers almost instantly started to utilize our parking facilities again, which
resulted in a strong recovery of our short-term parking revenues and operating cash flows, which
continued through the end of the summer of 2020. Even with short-term parking revenue in the third
quarter of 2020 continuing to be negatively affected by the absence of mass events, the closure of
hospitality and entertainment venues, nationwide working from home policies and continued
restrictions on travel, we estimate that across all of our jurisdictions of operations our revenue for the
third quarter ended September 30, 2020 reached approximately 76% of our revenue generated during
the third quarter ended September 30, 2019.

The resurgence of the virus in the fourth quarter of 2020 and the corresponding imposition of further
lockdown measures led to a renewed significant decrease in short-term parking revenues. At the same
time, our contract parking revenue increased by 5.5% in the year ended December 31, 2020 compared
to the year ended December 31, 2019. In addition, our management contracts remained relatively less
impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic, with our revenue from management contracts for the year ended
December 31, 2020 amounting to €155.6 million compared to €173.5 million in the year ended
December 31, 2019.

Our management reacted quickly to the COVID-19 pandemic and established a cross-functional
COVID-19 response team, which focuses on safeguarding the health and safety of our employees and
consumers and limiting the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on our business. In particular, in March
2020, management implemented strict cash management controls, including (i) a bottom-up, 17-week
rolling cashflow forecast and (ii) the deferral of non-essential capital expenditures, which resulted in a
reduction of our non-new business capital expenditures to €17.7 million (compared to €22.5 million in
the year ended December 2019). These cash management controls resulted in reductions in total capital
expenditures (excluding finance leases) in 2020 compared to the original budget for that year of €10.3
million, of which €9.9 million was deferred to 2021. In addition, we implemented stringent operational
and overhead cost reduction measures, including an immediate freeze on all temporary and new hiring,
a reduction in headcount of 736 employees, particularly in our parking attendant and airport staff
numbers, and furloughing approximately 20% of our non-directly revenue generating operational and
overhead staff. Furthermore, we leveraged government programs, such as flexi-time and furlough
arrangements and fixed cost recovery support schemes, in order to further reduce our cost base. These
measures resulted in cost reductions compared to the original 2020 budget of approximately €44
million, or 17% of our total non-rent costs, in the period March 1 to December 31, 2020.

##### 85


-----

In March 2020, we initiated a rent waiver and deferral program across our entire business, which
included the re-negotiation of lease contracts with the aim to defer rent payments and temporarily reduce
or move fixed rent structures to variable rent structures. In addition, we invoked existing contractual
protection clauses, such as clauses allowing rent adjustments in the case of an under-utilization of
parking facilities, to further reduce our rent payments. These rent reduction measures, coupled with the
benefit of reduced variable rent costs due to lower revenues, resulted in rent savings of approximately
€125 million in the year ended December 31, 2020 compared to the original budget for that year.

In May and June 2020, we also raised additional liquidity in an aggregate amount net of costs of €68
million in the form of an additional term loan facility. Furthermore, in May 2020, our shareholders,
Centerbridge and SVP Global provided us with an equity injection in the amount of €40 million.

In addition to implementing measures to safeguard our business, we also continued to focus on
providing consumers of our parking facilities with the best possible customer service given the
circumstances, including by keeping our parking facilities open as much as possible as people were
advised to avoid public transportation, decreasing physical contact points by enabling and promoting
digital payment and contactless and cashless parking solutions and leveraging our online pre-booking
tools. These efforts resulted in high retention rate of 98% in line with previous years and new business
equivalent to €13.2 million in annualized Pre-IFRS 16 Contract Contribution during 2020, which we
expect will contribute significantly to our portfolio growth going forward.

While our business has been significantly impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic, the past fifteen months
also showed that as soon as restrictions are eased, people quickly start to return to our facilities,
corresponding to a direct recovery in revenues. Our liquidity position remains stable and we believe
that the continued roll-out of vaccination programs across our markets will contribute to the acceleration
of our recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic.

**Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations**

**_Demand for Parking Services_**

Our revenues and profitability are affected by industry-wide megatrends which drive demand for our
parking services.

Growth in the European parking industry is driven by increasing urbanization across Europe, as well as
an increased mobility of urban populations, with cars historically accounting for more than 80% of
passenger transport in the European Union. These trends have led to a significant growth of the overall
vehicle fleet in Europe, which has increased by between 12 and 15 million vehicles per year between
2013 and 2019, and stood at over 240 million vehicles at the end of 2019. While this growth trend was
reversed in 2020 as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, when new car registrations in Europe decreased
by approximately 24%, the total number of vehicles in Europe remained relatively stable. At the same
time, traffic volumes and, in turn, demand for parking services are negatively affected by increased
consumer reliance on car sharing and taxi services, such as Uber, which provide alternatives to private
vehicle usage. In addition, cities and municipalities are expanding their public transportation networks
as they seek to control the flow of traffic through their town and city centers, which may result in
reduced car traffic. Furthermore, increased regulation of the car industry, such as the phase-out of
combustion engines across Europe as well as road user charges, such as London’s congestion charge
and Oslo’s road tolls, can lead to a reduction in the level of traffic, as well as stagnating demand for
parking spaces.

**_Type of Contract_**

We provide parking management services and parking enforcement services through a combination of
lease contracts and management contracts.

##### 86


-----

_Lease Contracts_

Lease contracts are medium-term contracts with a typical initial duration of ten to fifteen years, with an
option to extend for another five to ten years mostly at our sole discretion. Under our lease contracts,
we are typical responsible for running the parking operations at the relevant parking facility. In turn,
we receive parking fees directly from the consumer using the parking facility and pay rent to the lessor
or owner of the underlying asset. Rent payments under our lease contracts are usually in a combination
of fixed rent payments, which accounted for 42% of rent payments in the year ended December 31,
2019 (on a Pre-IFRS 16 basis), and variable rent payments that are linked to, for example, the amount
of parking fees collected. In addition, under our lease contracts, we are typically responsible for all
operating expenses of the relevant parking facility, such as personnel expenses, cost of materials and
other operating expenses as well as all capital expenditure for parking equipment. We often have full
pricing autonomy under our lease contracts, except at locations where the landlord wishes to retain
authority for parking tariffs such as airports and shopping centers.

In the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020 and the twelve months ended March 31, 2021,
lease contracts accounted for 76%, 76%, 71% and 69%, respectively, of our total revenue . Furthermore,
in the year ended December 31, 2019, lease contracts accounted for 96% of revenue in Denmark, 83%
in Sweden, 97% in Norway, 84% in Italy, 84% in Germany and 19% in the United Kingdom.

As of March 31, 2021, we had approximately 7,000 sites under lease agreements.

_Management Contracts_

Management contracts have a typical duration of three to eight years. Under our management contracts,
we receive fees from the site owner or lessor to cover our costs for running a site in addition to a fee for
managing the site. We can also generate revenue from equipment sales to our clients. The management
fees that we receive under our management contracts is typically adjusted on an annual basis based on
the consumer price index or other benchmark indices. We do not pay rent to our customers under our
management contracts but remain responsible for covering the underlying parking facility’s operating
expenses, such as personnel expenses, cost of materials and other operating expenses. Parking tariff
control and other strategic decisions related to the underlying parking facility remain with the owner or
lessor. As a result, we are not exposed to risk of fluctuating parking volume and instead focus our
activities on optimizing our operational performance.

Management contracts generally have lower margins than lease contracts as we are not exposed to any
revenue risk. However, our margins earned from management contracts are a function of a markup on
our operational costs, rather than consumer revenue less rent less operational costs for lease contracts,
and as a result on a percentage basis, management contract margins are not directly comparable to those
for lease contracts. Total management contract revenue includes that shown as ‘management
agreements’ in the fee type analysis, in addition to part of ‘other services’ which relates to charge-on of
costs to management contract clients. In the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020 and the
twelve months ended March 31, 2021, management contracts accounted for 24%, 24%, 29% and 31%,
respectively, of our total revenue. Furthermore, in the year ended December 31, 2019, management
contracts accounted for 4% of revenue in Denmark, 17% in Sweden, 3% in Norway, 16% in Italy, 16%
in Germany and 81% in the United Kingdom.

As of March 31, 2021, we had approximately 4,700 sites under lease agreements.

**_Pricing_**

Our results of operations are impacted by the pricing of parking tariffs at our parking facilities.

We generally determine parking fees based on supply and demand at individual parking locations. In
addition, we set parking tariffs with reference to the local competitive environment for alternative
locations in the immediate vicinity of our parking facilities. The level of pricing for our parking tariffs

##### 87


-----

typically also depends on the parking fee type, with rates for short-term parking generally being higher
than rates for long-term parking. Furthermore, the parking fees are impacted by regulation: regulation
affects the level of supply, through controlling new developments, the pricing of on-street parking, and
the amount of available free parking. Lastly, regulations affect the demand for our parking facilities
through policies that discourage vehicle traffic, such as congestion charges and other urban planning
measures, and the promotion of mass transit alternatives.

We continue to optimize our pricing structure through the roll-out of our data-driven dynamic pricing
model, which allows us to adjust our parking tariffs based on the location of a parking facility, the time
and day, demand at a particular parking facility and the duration of stay.

**_Fee Type_**

Our results of operations are affected by the type of parking fee charged. Our parking fees include (i)
short-term parking fees, (ii) fees from management agreements, (iii) contract parking fees and (iv) fees
from off-street parking facility monitoring.

(1) Primarily relates to refunds or cancellations of control fees.

Revenue for leased sites is comprised of a mix of short-term parking fees, contract parking fees and
control fees, although we do not always generate all types of fees from every site. For leased sites, our
revenue is generally related to the volume of consumers using these sites. In addition, we are usually
also responsible for collecting the consumer revenue at leased sites. To minimize our revenue collection
risk, we collect most of the short-term parking and contract parking fees at our leased sites either in
advance or at the point of utilization of the parking site.

Revenue for management sites is comprised of management fees, which are intended to cover both our
costs incurred in operating a site for a client and our fees for performing the management services.
Management fees are either fixed in total, which allows us to increase site profitability through cost
savings, or on an actual cost recovery basis, which results in cost saving programs benefitting the client,
plus a fixed management element.

In addition to our traditional fee types, we are seeing increasing demand for utilization of our parking
facilities as Urban Hubs. We consider income from our Urban Hubs to be incremental to income
generated from parking consumers as our Urban Hubs typically either utilize spare capacity at sites or
at times of the day when occupancy levels are generally lower, resulting in only limited overlap with
our other revenue streams. We plan to separately report revenue from our Urban Hubs once it becomes
material to the overall group.

##### 88


-----

_Short-Term Parking Fees_

Short-term parking fees are generated from shorter term parking customers, such as per-hour or per-day
tickets, under our lease contracts. We collect short-term parking fees directly from the short-term
parking customers in the form of cash or by debit or credit cards at the gates and physical barriers
present in our parking facilities. Short-term parking is typically charged at higher rates than long-term
parking, resulting in higher profitability per hour as compared to long-term parking. At the same time,
short-term parking exposes us to risks of lower level of parking facility utilization and, as a result,
greater volatility in revenue generation.

_Management Fees_

Management fees comprise fixed and variable fees generated under our management contracts with
third parties, including public authorities and private landlords and can be across all the main sectors in
which we operate. The level of management fees for a particular asset is typically agreed for the duration
of the management contract and is typically adjusted on an annual basis based on the consumer price
index as well as other benchmark indices, such as the London Living Wage. Given their relatively fixed
nature, management fees provide us with revenue stability and visibility over the duration of the
management contract.

_Contract Parking Fees_

Contract parking fees describe fees generated from customers holding season tickets, including
monthly, quarterly and annual season tickets, under our lease contracts. Contract parking fees are fixed
for the duration of the agreement with the consumer and are typically subject to annual price escalations
and collected in advance of the period to which they relate. As a result, contract parking fees have
historically provided us with greater revenue stability compared to short-term parking fees.

_Parking Enforcement Services Fees_

The type of fees received under our parking enforcement services vary depending on whether our
contract is with private landlords (in the case of Parking Control (“PAC”) or Park & Guard services) or
with municipalities (in the case of “On-Street” services).

Under contracts with private landlords, we generate control fees which comprise revenue generated
from enforcement of parking on behalf of the owner or landlord of the parking facilities. Under these
contracts, we patrol privately-owned parking spaces and issue and collect parking control fees directly
from the consumer. We subsequently may pay a portion of the fees collected to the site landlord under
our lease agreements based on the level of fees collected.

In the case of “On-Street” services, we patrol parking spaces owned by public authorities and issue
parking fines, which the consumer pays directly to the municipality. Under such contracts, we receive
a management fee from the municipality for the provision of our enforcement services. These fees are
reported under the ‘management agreement’ fee type. We do not book any of the control fees and fines
as part of our revenue.

_Other Services_

Our revenue from other services mainly includes charge-on of certain costs to management contract
clients, fees charged to owners and landlords for services provided to them in connection with our
contacts, such as revenue generated from the sale of parking equipment, income generated from
advertising activities and valet parking services.

##### 89


-----

**_Contract Retention and New Business_**

Our results of operations are affected by our ability to win, retain and renew lease and management
contracts. As of March 31, 2021, we had 7,000 sites under lease contracts and 4,700 sites under
management agreements and to May 31, 2021 we have signed new contracts accounting for €6.4 million
of total Pre-IFRS 16 Contract Contribution. The amount of new contracts signed per year has continued
to increase in recent years, from €12.2 million in 2018, to €12.4 million in 2019 and €13.2 million in
2020, in each case, of total Pre-IFRS 16 Contract Contribution.

We have historically retained contracts accounting for more than 95% of our Pre-IFRS 16 Contract
Contribution in the past five years, which we believe is a result of our disciplined and proactive
approach to contract renewals for facilities that we consider desirable or less risky to our overall
business operations. In the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, we renewed contracts
accounting for €8.6 million, €11.3 million and €22.7 million of total Pre-IFRS 16 Contract Contribution,
respectively. Our win rate has also increased, from approximately 35% in 2016 to 60% in 2019 and
75% in 2020. As a result of the successful renewal of these contracts, the volume of contracts that is
due for renewal by the end of 2026 is significantly lower and only accounts for an aggregate €44.8
million of Pre-IFRS 16 Contract Contribution for the year ended December 31, 2019 representing on
average only 5% per annum across that period of our total Pre-IFRS 16 Contract Contribution for the
year ended December 31, 2019. As of March 31, 2021, the remaining average duration of our top 100
lease contracts was 14 years and of our top 100 management contracts was approximately six years, in
both cases based on 2019 Pre-IFRS 16 weighted average Contract Contribution. We believe that our
high client retention rate, coupled with lower volumes of contract renewals in the period through to
2026, have historically contributed, and will continue to contribute, to the stability of our revenue
generation and earnings visibility.

Despite the effect of the COVID-19 pandemic on our business, in the year ended December 31, 2020
and the three months ended March 31, 2021 we signed new contracts which we estimate will contribute
an aggregate amount of approximately €53.6 million to our revenue and approximately €13.2 million
to our Pre-IFRS 16 Contract Contribution and approximately €14.8 million to our revenue and
approximately €3.6 million to our Pre-IFRS 16 Contract Contribution, respectively. On average, the
Pre-IFRS 16 Contract Contribution margin of new business won during 2020 is approximately 500bps
above the existing core portfolio of contracts. Our unweighted pipeline of new contracts has constantly
remained high, amounting to approximately €66 million, €67 million, €78 million and €80 million of
Pre-IFRS 16 Contract Contribution in the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020 and the
twelve months ended March 31, 2021, respectively. Prior to entering into a new contract for a parking
facility, we assess the optimum level of investment for that facility in order to increase its profitability
and produce a suitable return on our investment. Our level of investment will in turn depend on whether
or not we believe that the facility in question would benefit from extensive investment in the redesign
and addition of APCOA-specific features, such as APCOA FLOW and ANPR technology, which would
be typical for attractive locations with expected high demand for high quality parking, such as in the
City & Shopping sector. We typically agree a lower level of investment in facilities where cash flows
are less certain and/or there is a limited opportunity to realize financial benefits from our branding and
design. We typically recoup or initial investment after one to two years in the case of lease contracts
and less than one year in the case of management contracts. Contract Contribution recognized in the
year from new contracts increased from €8 million in 2016 to €13 million in 2019.

**_Cost Structure_**

Our results of operations are affected by our cost structure. Our cost structure mainly comprises fixed
costs, such as fixed rent payments, overhead personnel costs and costs associated with our parking
facilities, such as costs for maintenance and repairs and ancillary costs, which accounted for
approximately 40% of our costs in the year ended December 31, 2019 (on a Pre-IFRS 16 basis), as well
as semi-variable costs, such as operational staff, cleaning costs, costs related to snow removal, travel
and equipment repairs, which accounted for approximately 30% of our cost base in the year ended
December 31, 2019 (on a Pre-IFRS 16 basis). In addition, in the year ended December 31, 2019,

##### 90


-----

approximately 30% of our costs were variable (on a Pre-IFRS 16 basis), mainly consisting of variable
rents and payment card processing fees.

_Rent_

Lease expenses, or rent, comprises fixed lease payments as well as performance-based variable lease
payments, which are generally calculated on a percentage of the sales revenue generated from the
underlying leased site. In the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, 57%, 58% and 46%,
respectively, of our pre-IFRS 16 rent expenses were variable. The fixed rent component under our lease
contracts is periodically adjusted based on the consumer price index or other benchmark indices. Our
total rent expenses amounted to €356.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2016 (of which €126.1
million was fixed and €230.6 million was variable), €321.5 million in the year ended December 31,
2017 (of which €129.0 million was fixed and €192.5 million was variable), €318.6 million in the year
ended December 31, 2018 (of which €136.8 million was fixed and €181.8 million was variable), €344.7
million for the year ended December 31, 2019 (of which €144.0 million was fixed and €200.6 million
was variable) and €262.2 million in the year ended December 31, 2020 (of which €141.1 million was
fixed and €121.1 million was variable), in each case, before giving effect to the application of IFRS 16.
Excluding the effects of IFRS 16, our comparatively low rent expenses for the year ended December
31, 2020 reflect a decrease in variable rents as a result of reduced revenue from lease contracts due to
the COVID-19 pandemic during that year. In addition, in connection with the COVID-19 pandemic,
during the year ended December 31, 2020, we received government grants on a country-by-country
basis to offset fixed costs (including fixed lease payments, office rent, other operational expenditures
and other overhead expenses).

_Personnel Expenses_

Our personnel expenses constitute the second largest part of our cost structure after lease expenses.
Personnel expenses are largely fixed and semi-variable and include wages and salaries as well as social
security payments. During the year ended December 31, 2020, we benefitted from a number of
government aid programs set up in response to the COVID-19 pandemic in the jurisdictions in which
we operate our business. Pursuant to these programs, we received government grants in an aggregate
amount of €8.4 million, which were recognized as a reduction in personnel expenses in our 2020
Audited Financial Statements. In addition, during the COVID-19 pandemic, we took advantage of
employment support programs, such as Kurzarbeit in Germany, Cassa Integrazione in Italy, temporary
unemployment in Belgium and the furlough scheme in the United Kingdom.

_Cost of Materials and Purchased Services_

Our cost of materials are largely variable or semi-variable in nature and include (i) maintenance repair
costs and expenses for the repair of technical equipment, (ii) expenses for other external services, such
as payments in connection with external parking space monitoring and expenses for payment cards and
cleaning services, (iii) expenses for energy and other utilities and (iv) the costs of general operating
supplies, such as Pay & Display machines.

_Other Expenses_

Other operating expenses are mainly fixed in nature and include audit and consulting costs, information
technology expenses, expenses for temporary workers, expenses related to our fleet, travel expenses
and expenses for telecommunications. In the year ended December 31, 2020, we significantly reduced
our other operating expenses in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, by terminating and furloughing
temporary employees (resulting in a €2.5 million reduction in other operating expenses), cancelling
nearly all business travel (resulting in a €2.2 million reduction in other operating expenses),
streamlining our vehicle fleet (resulting in a €1.2 million reduction in other operating expenses) and
severely limiting our marketing expenses (resulting in a €0.9 million reduction in other operating
expenses).

##### 91


-----

**_Cost Savings and Efficiency Programs_**

Starting in 2017, we implemented several cost savings and operational efficiency initiatives focused on
(i) driving productivity in our control fee business line, (ii) optimizing site costs and (iii) reducing
central and procurements costs.

In order to increase the productivity in our control fee revenue stream, we optimized the deployment
and routing of parking attendants based on site occupancy, traffic congestion and historical hit rates.
We also minimized unproductive hours by starting the routes directly on site, reduced sickness rates
and used means of transportation reflecting the local traffic situation.

To optimize site costs across our business, we implemented group-wide benchmarks and best practices,
resulting in a streamlined FTE headcount and pooled resources to minimize overcapacity. We also
adjusted third-party services and reduced utilities costs.

To streamline our central and procurement costs, we implemented pooled customer service functions
cross-country, we digitized back-office processes and implemented self-administrative contract parker
platforms. In addition, we took steps to bundle our procurement activities across our entire business to
leverage our scale and generate cross-country synergies.

We estimate that these measures have resulted in total cost savings of approximately €10 million across
2017-2019, in addition to the various measures and savings introduced in 2020 in response to the
COVID-19 pandemic which are discussed elsewhere in this document.

**_Increased Digitization_**

Our business and results of operations are impacted by the increasing digitization of the parking
industry, which drives volumes and has resulted in parking convenience being a key factor when
deciding where to park. To grow our business, we increasingly rely on digital marketing, including a
robust social media presence, which continues to be a key driver of parking volumes. In addition, we
are increasing the use of our online sales and pre-booking platforms, which allow consumer to pre-book
parking spaces and purchase season tickets online. Between 2015 and 2019, the number of online prebooking services more than tripled. Furthermore, we believe that the increasing digitization of the
parking industry allows for new partnerships with participants across the broader automotive landscape,
such as fleet lessors, fuel card managers and parking services providers, which drive volumes at existing
sites and which we expect will provide for additional revenue streams, such as subscription fees for
partners’ services offered through our websites, in the future. To respond to the increased demand for
digital parking services, we launched our apps “APCOA Connect” in the United Kingdom and the
Republic of Ireland in 2012 as well as “APCOA FLOW” in Denmark, Germany, Italy, Norway, Austria,
Poland and Sweden from 2018, which enables consumers to access mobile, contactless on- and offstreet parking services. We estimate that we generated revenues of approximately €35 million through
these apps in the year ended December 31, 2019.

In addition, the digitization of the parking industry has allowed us to generate revenues from new
parking and services concepts, such as storage opportunities for logistics providers, virtual car rental
services and electronic vehicle charging, which we continue to roll out across our business through our
Urban Hubs initiative.

(excluding the impact of IFRS 16 for years after December 31, 2018) for the ones conducted in the
years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, respectively. Between January 2019 and March 31,

**_Foreign Currency Effects_**

We operate car parks in 13 countries of which six countries, the United Kingdom, Sweden, Norway,
Denmark, Poland and Switzerland do not use the euro, our reporting currency, as their national currency.
Accordingly, our results of operations are subject to currency effects, primarily currency translation

##### 93


-----

exposure; transaction-related exposures at our subsidiaries are limited because revenue and costs are
largely incurred in their respective operating currencies. For our subsidiaries in countries with a
functional currency other than euro, income and losses are translated into euro at average exchange
rates, and assets and liabilities are translated into euro at closing exchange rates. Fluctuations in
exchange rates against the euro will give rise to period-on-period differences in our results of operations.
In the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020 and the three months ended March 31, 2021,
50%, 52%, 57% and 60%, respectively, of our revenue for such periods was reported by subsidiaries
whose functional currencies are different than the euro, primarily the British pound sterling, the Danish
krone, the Norwegian krone, Polish zloty, Swedish krona and Swiss franc. We are also subject to foreign
currency effects linked to loans denominated in currencies other than the functional currency of the
entity that holds the loan, which creates unrealized foreign currency gains and/ or losses depending on
the fluctuation of the underlying foreign exchange rates.

**Liquidity and Capital Resources**

Our primary liquidity requirements are to service our debt, fund our operations and for other general
corporate purposes. Our ability to generate cash from our operations depends on our future operating
performance, which is in turn dependent, to some extent, on general economic, financial, competitive,
market, legislative, regulatory and other factors, many of which are beyond our control, as well as other
factors including those discussed in this section and the section entitled “Risk Factors.” Following the
completion of the Transactions, we expect that our principal sources of liquidity will be cash flows from
operations as well as drawings under our New Revolving Credit Facility. See “Description of Certain
_Financing Arrangements—New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement.”_

To manage our liquidity and working capital needs, we have entered into certain cash management
arrangements with Deutsche Bank. These arrangements are provided to us on customary terms in the
ordinary course of business and include, amongst others, zero balancing cash pooling and the collection
of direct debits. We will continue to utilize these services following the Issue Date. Any obligations
arising in connection with these cash management arrangements may be secured on the Collateral in
priority to the Notes.

In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, in the year ended December 31, 2020, we implemented a
number of measures to safeguard our liquidity, including drawing down a new €78 million term loan
facility (which resulted in additional liquidity of €68 million net of costs) and accessing €40 million of
funds provided by our Sponsor. Furthermore, we made selective use of economic stimulus and
government support programs where available, including furlough programs and government grants to
assist with lease payments. In addition, we reduced or postponed investments and expenses and, in
particular, we implemented a sustainable reduction in maintenance capital expenditures, introduced

##### 102


-----

short-time working arrangements for employees and reduced or deferred lease and rental payments in
agreement with our landlords.

We anticipate that we will be highly leveraged for the foreseeable future and our ability to generate
future financing cash flows will be limited by the Indenture and New Revolving Credit Facility
Agreement, which may have important negative consequences for you. See “Risk Factors,”
“Description of the Notes—Certain Covenants” and “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements.”
Any additional indebtedness that we incur could reduce the amount of our cash flow available to make
payments on our then existing indebtedness, including under the Notes offered hereby, and increase our
leverage.

**Capital Expenditures**

Our capital expenditures include (i) expansion capital expenditures comprising new business and digital
infrastructure capital expenditures, (ii) renewal capital expenditures, (iii) maintenance capital
expenditures and (iv) cars & overhead capital expenditures. Our capital expenditures exclude, in each
case, finance leases.

Expansion capital expenditures comprise new business and digital infrastructure capital expenditures:

- New business capital expenditures relate to investments in new business contracts in order to
get them operational. Examples include the new installation or the replacement of prior operator
equipment with new parking equipment (barrier systems, lane branding, servers, cash machines
and other payment points).

- Digital infrastructure capital expenditures relate to investments in our digitalization strategy,
including the inclusion of the car park onto our FLOW platform.

Renewal capital expenditures comprises investments related to renewed contracts and include the
upgrade of existing equipment or refurbishing the appearance of car parks (new lane branding, paint,
lighting etc.).

Maintenance capital expenditures relate to the maintenance of car parks within our lease portfolio.
Examples include necessary repairs of broken equipment, lighting, or regulatory required upgrades, for
example to cash or card payment machines.

Car & overhead capital expenditures include investments in cars for operational and overhead staff as
well as investments related to headquarters or non-operational functions, such as ERP updates,
information technology hardware & software.

The level of capital expenditures at any given parking facility varies depending on whether the facility
is subject to a lease or management contract. Our total capital expenditures in the years ended December
31, 2018 and 2019 were relatively stable at €32.2 million and €37.1 million, respectively. In response
to the COVID-19 pandemic situation, in the year ended December 31, 2020, we deferred all nonessential capital expenditures to 2021, resulting in a reduction of our non-growth capital expenditures
by 9.4%, to €10.6 million, in the year ended December 31, 2020. We also deferred some growth capital
expenditures to 2021, resulting in a reduction of our expansion capital expenditure by 28.0%, to € 13.6
million, in the year ended December 31, 2020.
