**Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Financial Risk Management**

We are exposed to financial risks in the form of liquidity risks, tax risks, credit risks, currency risk and
interest rate risk during the course of our ordinary business activities.

##### 107


-----

Non-financial or non-quantifiable risks, such as business risks or reputational risks, are not considered
here.

**_Liquidity Risks_**

Liquidity risks relate to the prospect of our Group not being able to fulfil its financial obligations. We
manage our liquidity by maintaining liquid reserves and bank credit lines alongside the cash inflows
from its operating business, and by having access to the capital market through continuous dialogue.
Operational liquidity management comprises the daily pooling of liquid funds in the Group’s cash pool,
which the Group Treasury function coordinates. In this way, liquidity surpluses and shortages can be
managed both in accordance with the requirements of the Group as a whole and those of the individual
Group companies.

For budget planning purposes, a monthly liquidity plan was prepared for 2021, which was updated and
extended to 2022. Liquidity at the level of both the Group and the national companies is monitored
continuously. A Group liquidity status report is compiled daily for this purpose. In addition, regularly
(once a week in times of large uncertainty, every three weeks in times of more stability) all units prepare
a rolling 17-week liquidity forecast by planning category.

Since March 2020, our liquidity risk has increased due to the COVID-19 pandemic and its impact on
our revenue. We introduced a number of early and comprehensive measures in response to the COVID19 pandemic to safeguard our liquidity. See “—Liquidity and Capital Resources.”

**_Tax Risks_**

Tax risks can arise for our Group if local tax authorities fail to agree with our assessment of a specific
case. This risk is taken into consideration by obtaining tax advice and monitoring the relevant matters.
The resulting tax risks could have a moderate short-term bearing on our finances.

**_Credit Risks_**

Credit risks arise from the possibility that contractual partners to a transaction prove unable to fulfil
their financial obligations, thereby causing financial losses for our Group. Receivables default risks are
low as a result of our business model. This risk is further minimized by the wide geographical
distribution of such receivables, and their spread across a large number of individual debtors. The
elevated default risk in the parking facility management business unit arising from non-payers is
reflected through value adjustments to individual accounts receivables.

**_Currency Risks_**

Currency risks for our Group arise primarily from investments, financing measures and operative
activities. Our national subsidiaries are provided with the necessary financial means in their local
currencies so that no significant currency risks are generated for the national subsidiaries. We do not
hedge against currency risks that do not influence the Group’s cash flow (risks arising from the currency
conversion of foreign financial statements into the Group’s reporting currency, so-called translation
risks). As debt funding for our Group is provided in the Group currency (euro) and partly differs from
the currencies of the local APCOA companies, a translation risk arises from exchange rate fluctuations.
This risk is monitored on a monthly basis with hedging measures being implemented where required.
Additionally, currency risks arising from cash flows are monitored on a monthly basis.

**_Interest Rate Risks_**

Risks of interest rate changes arise based on potential changes in the market interest rates and can lead
to a change in the fair value of fixed-interest financial instruments, and fluctuations in interest payments
on variable interest rate financial instruments. In the medium term, we expect interest rates to remain
low and assess the risk of substantial rate increases to be minor. The relevant reference interest rate of

##### 108


-----

our Group is EURIBOR, and due to the agreed floor of 0%, a slight increase does not affect interest
payments. Based on this assessment and to avoid additional financial costs (especially front-end fees),
we have currently decided against interest rate hedging of our variable rate liabilities. Following the
Offering, we will be exposed to additional interest risk. See “Risk Factors—The Floating Rate Notes
_and drawings under the New Revolving Credit Facility will bear interest at floating rates that could_
_rise significantly, increasing our costs and reducing our cash flow.” The company monitors and assess_
interest rate risks on a monthly basis so it can react quickly to changes in the market.

**Critical Accounting Policies**

Our management must make certain estimates and assumptions that affect the amounts reported in the
Financial Statements, based on historical experience, existing and known circumstances, authoritative
accounting pronouncements and other factors that management believes to be reasonable, but actual
results could differ materially from these estimates. The full impact of the COVID-19 pandemic is
unknown and cannot be reasonably estimated for these key estimates. However, we made appropriate
accounting estimates based on the facts and circumstances available as of the reporting date. To the
extent there are differences between these estimates and actual results, our Financial Statements may
be materially affected.

We apply estimates and judgments by management especially in the following accounting policies.

**_Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic_**

Our business activities have been significantly affected by the pandemic and the associated uncertainties
since March 2020. In particular, due to the still not fully foreseeable global consequences of the
COVID-19 pandemic, the estimates and discretionary decisions made in connection with the assets and
liabilities reported in the balance sheet are subject to a greater level of uncertainty.

In updating the estimates and judgements, management took into account the information available
concerning expected economic trends and country-specific government policies.

This information was included particularly in impairment tests for the cash-generating units; in the case
of impairment of trade receivables, the expected credit loss model was reviewed in relation to the
assessment of future economic conditions in the context of COVID-19. Furthermore, this information
was taken into account in the tax planning prepared by the Norwegian subsidiary, as sufficient taxable
income exists in the long-term against which the loss carry forwards can be offset.

**_Trade Receivables_**

All trade receivables are initially recognized at the transaction price and subsequently adjusted for
impairment to reflect the expected default. The calculation is based on historical default rates, which
are adjusted to reflect current economic developments. As a rule, a decline in the volume of receivables
reduces such value adjustments on a portfolio basis accordingly, and vice versa. If individual
receivables are at risk of default, estimates and assessments based on the respective client’s
creditworthiness are included.

**_Impairment_**

The determination of the recoverable amount of a cash generating unit, an asset and an intangible asset
with an indefinite useful life is based on management estimates. The recoverable amount is the higher
of the fair value less costs to sell, and value in use. Management normally determines these values in
line with valuation methods based on discounted cash flows. These discounted cash flows are calculated
on the basis of five-year forecasts which are prepared in line with financial plans authorized by the
Management Board. The cash flow forecasts take into consideration historical data and are based on the
Management Board’s best estimates of future development. Cash flows beyond the planning period are
extrapolated applying a standard growth rate that is determined in consideration of the expected long
##### 109


-----

term development potential of the relevant markets and publicly available long-term inflation
expectations as well as the possibility of passing these on to customers in the form of price increases.
Weighted average costs of capital are utilized to discount the cash flows. These are based on a peer
group and were determined using capital market data. The most important assumptions on which the
determination of fair value less costs to sell and value in use is based include estimated cash flows,
estimated growth rates, weighted average costs of capital, and tax rates. The measurement of intangible
assets with indeterminable useful lives is additionally dependent on the underlying license rates. These
premises and their underlying methodology can have a significant impact on the respective values and
ultimately on the amount of possible impairment of goodwill, intangible assets with indefinite useful
lives, and other assets.

**_Pensions and Similar Obligations_**

Obligations for pensions and similar commitments and related expenses and income are calculated in
accordance with actuarial valuations. Such valuations are based on key assumptions, including
discounting factors, wage and pension trends, and life expectancies. The discount factor applied reflects
the interest rates that can be achieved as of the balance sheet date for high-value fixed-interest
investments with matching maturities. The underlying assumptions can differ from actual outcomes due
to a fluctuating market and economic situation. This can exert significant effects on the obligations of
pensions and other post-retirement benefits. The resultant differences are recognized directly in other
comprehensive income under equity in the period in which they arise, and do not affect profit and loss
as a consequence.

**_Other Provisions_**

The calculation of provisions is associated with significant estimates. Other provisions are formed for
a large number of individual risks whose payment dates or amounts are uncertain. Determining these
other provisions requires the making of estimates. These provisions also relate to provisions against
risks arising from legal disputes and processes, insofar as these fulfil the criteria for making provisions.
Assessing the level of such provisions entails not only an assessment of circumstances in the specific
case that is being asserted, but also making recourse to the results of comparable proceedings and
appraisals by lawyers and other factors, as well as assumptions about event probabilities and the
bandwidths of potential utilization.

**_Income Tax_**

The recognition of tax provisions is based on estimates. It should also be determined whether the
recognition of deferred tax assets is permitted, or whether a valuation adjustment to deferred tax assets
is required. The likelihood that deferred tax assets arising from timing differences and losses carried
forward can be offset against taxable profits in the future must be evaluated. Deferred tax assets must
also be recognized to the extent that sufficient taxable temporary differences are available. Uncertainties
exist concerning the interpretation of complex tax regulations as well as concerning the amount and
date of future taxable income.

**Leasing**

The measurement of liabilities from leases and rights of use assets requires assumptions to be made
regarding key parameters or their probabilities and dates of occurrence or exercise, as well as the
determination of an appropriate capitalization rate. In determining the term of leases, all facts and
circumstances that provide an economic incentive to exercise renewal options or not to exercise
termination options are taken into consideration. Term changes arising from the exercise of renewal or
termination options are only included in the contract term if their exercise is reasonably certain. For
APCOA PARKING Group this is regularly the case if the exercise option lies within the detailed
planning period and is reflected in planning.

##### INDUSTRY

_In this section, we rely on and refer to information regarding our business and the market in which we_

_obtained from publicly available information and independent industry publications and reports._

_In many cases, there is no readily available external information (whether from trade associations,_

**Introduction**

Parking plays a pivotal role in daily activity around private and professional mobility, local and
international travel, leisure and general location based activities, transportation, quality of life and
environmental issues. Generally, the parking infrastructure and parking operations and management
business, has limited demand risk and limited direct competition. Additionally, the industry benefits
from a degree of regulatory protection and stability because it provides a critical service to
municipalities. The number of car parking spaces has been growing in Europe driven by a variety of
factors which include urbanization and an increase in the number of cars. The profitability of the sector
is generally improving, supported by scale efficiencies, the implementation of cost savings programs
and the utilization of digital based technologies, among others.

In aggregate, there are 24 million parking spaces in APCOA’s geographies, of which approximately
60% are off-street and 40% are on-street. APCOA’s top 6 countries (Germany, United Kingdom, Italy,
Sweden, Denmark and Norway) account for 18 million of these spaces, of which 11 million are offstreet.

Despite approximately 40% of European parking spaces being on-street, major industry players are
focused on the off-street segment due to legislation that restricts private operators from operating onstreet car spaces. Parking spaces located in cities and shopping centers are the two largest sectors in
Europe, accounting for 70% of regulated off-street parking spaces.

**Parking Market by Segment**

Based on segment, the parking market is divided between on-street and off-street car parks.

**On-street parking spaces are regulated spaces on the roadway with some type of signaling, control or**
surveillance and can be paid or be for free. Parking is short-term, and this segment is typically very
much exposed to city policies and regulatory changes. In this segment, parking operators usually offer
meter management services (i.e. management and maintenance of parking meters) and revenue
collection (i.e. issuance and collection of fines through enforcement services) on behalf of the
municipality.

**Off-street parking spaces are parking spaces for public-use in dedicated facilities. These can be both**
indoor and outdoor, single or multi-storey and used short-term (hourly) or long-term (monthly and
yearly). They tend to be located in high footfall locations e.g. city centers and airports. These spaces
can be: i) publicly or privately managed; ii) paid or for free, and; iii) in-structure or on-surface. Instructure parking refers to multilevel or underground car parks while on-surface refers to uncovered car
parks at street level with horizontal signs and access control (barrier, attendant, ANPR etc.). An
additional category of off-street parking is Park & Ride, consisting of parking spaces close to coach,

##### 112


-----

rail stations or other means of transport that allow commuters to leave their vehicle and commute via
bus, rail, etc. for the remainder of the journey.

The off-street segment is the most relevant in terms of overall economics generated given the
significantly higher revenue per space and EBITDA margins compared to on-street (lower margin
profile for on-street parking is primarily driven by cost-plus outsourcing enforcement contracts).

Within off-street parking, spaces located in cities and shopping centers represent the largest segment
accounting for c. 70% of the total outsourced market, followed by spaces located in airports.

**Car Parking Location**

Parking spaces located in city and shopping centers and airports account for a large proportion of the
market.

Parking spaces located in city and shopping centers typically have high turnover with shorter stays
lasting a few hours or a day. Landlords are mainly municipalities, infrastructure funds, companies,
private investors, shopping centre operators / owners in addition to a large number of less sophisticated
private landlords.

Parking spaces located in airports typically have a lower rotation given travelling passengers stay for
days to weeks at a time (except for drop-off parkers). Landlords are mainly sophisticated airport
operators / owners given the importance and size of the business with relevant negotiation power upon
contract renewal. Given the growing importance of car parking economics within airport activities, in
a few cases airport operators have decided to keep the management of parking spaces in-house in order
to realize all car park economics despite a lack of operating experience. Contracts are usually large and
the underlying volume risk is linked to air traffic volume. Volume risk is mitigated by an ongoing shift
in the airport parking market to management contracts (primarily fixed fee) and the introduction of
specific clauses within lease agreements limiting downside risks for airport parking operators.

**Parking Market by Operating Model**

By operating model, the car park market can be split by: (i) management contracts, (ii) lease contracts,
(iii) concessions and (iv) full ownership.

**Management contracts represent service agreements with short to mid-term contract length, usually**
3-8 years, where the operator is responsible for operating a car park on behalf of the landlord or
concession owner. Overall risks to the operator under these contracts are very limited given low
investments required, no exposure to traffic risk and limited location risk. Facility maintenance
activities are generally up to the landlord and other required investments are very limited from the
operator perspective. The operator is not subject to traffic risk as most contracts primarily involve fee
based payments given that strategic decisions like tariff policy, etc., remain with the landlord of the car
park. There is limited exposure to location risk given the length of these contracts.

Management contract business represent approximately 30-40% of total European market spaces, with
a typical contract contribution margin of 10-20%. The lower economics generated by this segment in
terms of revenue and margin can be explained by the lower underlying risk of the business, given a
revenue model based on broadly fixed fees agreed with the landlord, where the revenue generated by
the consumers that park go directly to the landlord, hence no volume risk, and limited investment and
location risks.

**Lease contracts represent rental agreements with mid-term contract lengths, usually between seven to**
20 years (including options to extend), where the operator runs the parking facility and pays an annual
rent to the lessor that can be fixed and/or variable depending on specific success factors. Overall risk
borne by the operator under these types of contracts is higher than with management contracts but
sensibly lower compared to concession and full ownership agreements, given lower investments

##### 113


-----

required, and lower location risk. Under lease contracts the operator is responsible for installation &
maintenance of parking equipment. Other investments required are usually limited and shared with the
landlord, however higher than the ones required under management contracts. The operator is subject
to full traffic exposure given the revenue stream is mainly based on car park ticket fares from users.
Lease contracts represent the largest proportion (approximately 40-50%) of total European market
spaces, with a typical contract contribution margin of 15-25%. There is limited location risk compared
to concession or full ownership agreements given the limited 7-20-year contract length.

**Concessions represent long-term contracts with duration typically between 30-50 (sometimes up to 99)**
years, where the operator acts as a temporary owner responsible also for building maintenance activities.
In greenfield concessions the operator is responsible for both building and operating the new car park
on behalf of a concession-owner to whom it pays royalties. In brownfield concessions the operator runs
an existing car park on behalf of a concession-owner to whom it pays royalties, but the operator is not
involved in the construction of the car park and hence initial investment requirements are lower than in
greenfield concessions. In both cases the operator is exposed to high investment requirements and full
traffic risk, given the revenue stream is mainly based on car park ticket fares from users. Furthermore,
the operator is subject to any long-term location risk that might arise.

Under **full ownership the operator owns the parking facilities. This model requires high capital**
investment including build-up of the facility or buy-out of existing property and ongoing maintenance
investments. The operator is exposed to high investment requirements and full short and long-term
traffic and location risk, given the revenue stream is mainly based on car park ticket fares from users.

By number of spaces, concession and full ownership operating models represent approximately 5-15%
of European parking spaces, with a typical contract contribution margin of 30-40%. Margins in this
segment are the highest in the market given the higher capital invested and risk exposure compared to
other operating models.

**Structural Growth Drivers of the Parking Sector**

**_Personal Car Fleet Growth and Urbanization_**

In Western Europe, the vehicle parc is expected to continue growing steadily at +0.8% CAGR from
2021-2025E, and remain an important driver of the parking industry’s turnover. Additionally, the
Western European urban population is forecasted to increase by +0.4% CAGR from 2021-2025E. This
increase is expected to drive demand for parking in cities.

**_Favorable Pricing Dynamics that Support Larger Companies_**

Larger companies in the parking industry benefit from the high barriers to entry, particularly in offstreet parking which include:

- Operational economies of scale which support the pricing and winning of new contracts

- Pricing power advantage stemming from operating car parks in close proximity to each other

Limited supply of new parking spaces, especially in city centers, which benefits the larger players with
established positions and long-term contracts

**_Shift in Cities from On-street to Off-street Parking_**

Across Europe, particularly in large city centers, local municipalities are disincentivising on-street
parking due to urban planning, traffic and environmental concerns. They continue to do this through
increasing pricing, reducing spaces and introducing maximum allowed parking times.

**_Increasing Level of Outsourcing_**

Outsourcing share of parking operations is expected to grow for a number of reasons, which include the
need of owners to maximize utilization of their assets, increased adoption of technologies e.g. digital,
economies of scale and budget pressures on local municipalities.

As of 2018, the level of outsourcing across APCOA’s countries of operations was approximately 40%
and there remains significant opportunity for an increase in outsourcing share, particularly in Germany.

**_Pricing Inflation_**

Pricing inflation, driven by relatively low price elasticity and advanced pricing techniques is expected
across sectors, especially in city centers.

**_Net New Build_**

Increasing net new build is driven by construction activity, supported by low interest rates, high liquidity
and growing demand for parking across most sectors.

**Industry Trends**

**_Car Sharing and Autonomous Vehicles_**

The parking industry is expected to be shaped in the long-term by key global trends such as the
increasing penetration of electric vehicles, connected cars and drivers, shared parking slots, autonomous
driving vehicles and a decline in car ownership.

Increase in electric vehicle usage and connectivity between cars and drivers is expected to have a
positive impact on the parking market growth by 2025. Electric vehicles are expected to bring additional
revenues for car park operators through fees for chargeable parking spaces. Increasing connectivity
between cars and drivers in parking slots (i.e. real time update on parking slot availability) is expected
to generate additional returns via dynamic pricing and increased stickiness to first-movers.

##### 116


-----

In five years’ time, shared parking slots could enable the entrance of new players in the market and
slow demand for traditional parking operators which, on the other hand, can leverage on their size to
execute acquisitions or partner with new operators.

In 2030–2040+ the “traditional” market is likely going to be impacted by increasing penetration of
shared AVs and robo-taxis leading to uptake of on-demand shared mobility which may dampen volume
growth of traditional parking. Beyond 2030, the market is expected to grow at 1.8–2.5% p.a.

Autonomous driving vehicles could represent the only real disruption in the market with cars potentially
able to look for cheaper parking nearby or free parking farther away from the drop-off location. It might
on the other hand offer greater opportunity for real individual & personalized transport. Given the
current status of autonomous development, this scenario is unlikely to breakthrough before 2025-2030.
Technical/regulatory barriers could further postpone and mitigate the envisaged long-term market
effects. Penetration of AVs is expected to reach 10–15% of total car parking by 2040 and is likely
leading to changes in the mobility landscape with the rise of shared mobility solutions driven by robotaxi fleets in large cities.

**_Technological Trends_**

The use of technology is increasing across the car parking sector. In more mature markets, technology
allows for more efficient use of parking facilities for car park users as well as an increase in revenue
and cost reduction for car parking operators. Operators increasingly leverage technology to enhance
their customer offering and yield management, leading to increased customer loyalty and repeat
business.

Recent examples of technological innovations include:

- **Automatic Number Plate Recognition (ANPR): integrates with various devices, such as**
access control systems and CCTV cameras, to capture images of vehicle license plates. Main
applications include ticketless parking fee management, parking access automation, vehicle
location guidance, car theft prevention, automated payment process and others

- **Electronic parking guidance systems: real-time message boards directing drivers to nearby**
parking facilities to help decrease the time required to locate a parking space. Major cities such
as Paris, Barcelona and Munich have installed such advanced parking guidance systems

- **CCTV: increasingly used as a crime management and enforcement tool**

- **Pay-by-phone: improves parking fee collection and the payment services can be outsourced to**
a third-party vendor, who charges customers a service fee, thereby passing down any costs
associated with the service to the customer, not the car park owner / operator

- **Payment apps: can provide consumers with the ability to pre-book, find parking locations, pay**
hands-free and return via loyalty programs

**_Mobility Hubs_**

New mobility trends are also enabling car parks to extend their offering and become mobility hubs by
leveraging their unique locations in city centers. As a result, the “traditional” car parking business will
be reshaped into a multi-revenue stream business. Car parks have the potential to become intermodal
mobility hubs, catering to new consumer needs such as EV charging, car sharing parking, last mile
vehicles parking (e.g. electric bikes).

New use cases enabled by mobility hubs will also emerge and allow car parking operators to diversify
and tap new revenue streams in last-mile distribution, delivery pick-up locations, food delivery or selfstorage. Multiple operators around the globe have recognized this trend and are developing new

##### 117

strategies. APCOA has a clear strategy going forward and is well positioned to capture the new market
opportunities.

##### BUSINESS

**Overview**

We are a leading parking infrastructure operator and services provider in the European market, with a
large and diversified portfolio of leased and managed parking facilities across 13 European countries.
We operate off-street parking facilities under leases from private and public landlords, and also operate
on- and off-street parking facilities for clients under management contracts. As of March 31, 2021, we
operated approximately 11,700 parking facilities with over 1.6 million parking spaces. We believe we
are either the leading or number two parking facility operator by number of parking spaces in each of
our ten largest country markets.

We benefit from a large, structurally attractive and growing parking market that we believe will benefit
from ongoing outsourcing, mobility and other industry trends such as growth in the number of vehicles
in Europe, urban areas, electric vehicle (“EV”) charging, car hiring and sharing and more recently use
of the car parks as infrastructure for the e-commerce value chain and customer delivery. During 2018,
the European parking market generated approximately €28 to 29 billion in revenues of which
approximately €11 to 12 billion was spent on outsourcing parking management. We believe we are well
positioned to capture the benefits from these trends and the general economic recovery from the
COVID-19 pandemic expected in 2021 and 2022 because we create significant, stable and recurring
value for our clients, for whom parking facilities are often a non-core operation, by providing a large
scale platform that is focused on driving higher revenues by increasing volume, pricing and utilization,
at a lower cost of operation.

Our operations benefit from a diverse portfolio of lease and management contracts as well as
geographical, business sector and customer diversification, which made our business more resilient
during the COVID-19 pandemic, while at the same time allowing us to leverage operational similarities
to benefit from scale economies. Our parking facilities are spread across most of Europe (with certain
clusters for operational efficiency) and apart from one large market (Germany), five other countries
(Denmark, Italy, Sweden, the United Kingdom and Norway) each contributed approximately 10% of
our Pre-IFRS 16 Contract Contribution in the year ended December 31, 2019. We operate in a wide
range of business sectors, such as city and shopping, travel, healthcare & education, events and
hospitality, and parking enforcement, with limited correlation between them. Furthermore, many of our
parking facilities are not dedicated to a single institution, business or purpose but are instead multifunctional and used by motorists that visit a variety of locations, whether it is for work, shopping,
restaurant or cultural activities, or other purposes. We have very low contract concentration, with over
5,900 contracts across over 11,700 parking facilities.

**Business Sector**


We have made significant investments in recent years in our information technology and digital delivery
in order to make our facilities and services more attractive to both motorists and landlords. We offer
motorists various services related to on-street and off-street parking via smartphone applications and
end customer-oriented websites. These services cover the entire parking customer experience, from
searching for and reserving a parking space, navigating to the parking garage, contactless entry and exit,
and electronic payment. This saves motorists from having to draw a ticket, walk to the ticket machine
or cash machine and pay with cash, making the parking process easier, faster and more comfortable for
the end customer. These digital services also allow for additional yield management through
differentiated pricing according to the number of available spaces, distribution channel, location and
size of specific parking spaces and customer groups.

We operate our clients’ parking assets through two business models, lease contracts and management
contracts. In each of these models, we run parking operations for our clients without incurring
significant capital expenditures and thus through an “asset light” approach that is flexible and scalable,
because we operate the facilities as opposed to owning them. Our long-term underlying contract
structures provide us with stability of revenues and the ability to forecast and plan. As of March 31,
2021, our average contract life (including extensions) for our top 100 contracts (based on weighted
average Pre-IFRS 16 Contract Contribution for the year ended December 31, 2019) was approximately
31 years with an average remaining life of approximately 12 years.

- _Lease Contracts. We lease parking sites from our clients, where we are responsible for running_
the parking operations and driving site-revenue. We receive parking fees directly from the
consumers parking in our leased sites and we pay rent to the lessor, either as a fixed rent, a
variable rent or a combination of fixed and variable rent payments. We focus on driving yield
at the site by increasing parking volume and price. We have a mix of short and long-term
parking customers at our leased sites. Short-term parking includes customers who pay on a perhour or per-day basis. Short-term parking generated 53% of our total revenues for the year
ended December 31, 2019. Long-term, or contract parking revenue, includes customers holding
season tickets, including monthly, quarterly and annual season tickets, and individual customers
and business customers who may contract for multiple spaces. Long-term contract parking
generated 11% of our revenues for the year ended December 31, 2019. Short-term parking
customers provide immediate payment in cash, by debit or credit cards, or through payment
apps at the location of our parking facilities. In addition, in some countries, including Norway
and Sweden, short-term parking customers are charged via invoice after the parking event has
been completed, for which we charge an additional fee payable by the consumer. Contract
parking customers provide advance payments which contribute to revenue stability and a
favorable net working capital profile. We are responsible for providing car parking technology
at the site and all expenses relating to operating and maintaining the parking equipment during
the term of the lease, with minimal responsibility for the physical upkeep of the facility and as

##### 120


-----

a result have limited capital expenditure obligations for maintenance of the facility. Our lease
contract business generated 76% of our revenue for the year ended December 31, 2019.

- _Management contracts. Our management business represents the fees we receive for managing_
parking facilities under contracts with third parties including public authorities as well as
private landlords and other private entities. Under these contracts we also advise on driving
revenue and traffic to the site. We are responsible for running the parking operations and
providing the car parking technology, which is often purchased through us but paid and owned
by the client. We are incentivized to meet a fixed contractual service level for which we receive
a fixed management fee from our client, and may also receive additional incentive fees. We do
not pay rent to our client, and the clients benefit from the fees paid by customers parking their
cars at these locations (which they receive either directly or through us, but which we typically
do not recognize as revenue). At sites under management contracts, we focus on maximizing
operational efficiency and scale and do not bear the risk of reduced traffic volumes and make
limited to no capital investments. Our management contract business generated 24% of our
revenue for the year ended December 31, 2019.

Our parking enforcement services (issuing penalty notices on private land and administering fines in
public spaces) help our clients increase parking compliance and safety and reduce abuse, over-stays and
unwanted parking. These services include the patrolling of parking facilities owned or leased by our
clients, the issuance and collection of parking fines, the management of debt collection and the provision
of impartial representation and appeals services. We offer our parking enforcement services mainly in
Germany, Austria, Belgium, Sweden, Norway, Denmark, Poland and the United Kingdom. In the year
ended December 31, 2019, we generated revenues of €157 million, or 21.8% of our total revenue from
parking enforcement services.

We also provide an extended range of ancillary services, including traffic management, taxi
management, shuttle management, valet parking, trolley services, parking space monitoring, security
and cleaning, advertising space marketing, e-solutions such as online booking platforms, apps and
electronic payment methods, collection services to parking facility owners as well as 24/7 support and
advising property owners on commercial and technical asset management as well as, in certain
circumstances, the planning, financing, construction and operation of multi-storey car parks and parking
spaces.

In addition, we have recently introduced “APCOA Urban Hubs,” which expands our core business
through new partnerships with participants across the mobility, logistics, electrification and technology
sectors. The COVID-19 pandemic led to the acceleration of the e-commerce penetration, on-demand
proximity services, proliferation of new mobility models and increased automation. These services
require substantial city-based infrastructure. Our APCOA Urban Hubs offer this infrastructure with
dedicated parking areas that can be used for alternative services, such as the long-term and short-term
storage of goods, trans-shipping for trucks and electric bikes for last mile deliveries, fleet parking for
logistics companies, shared vehicle and other mobility services and EV charging stations for fleet and
micro mobility like electric scooters and bikes. In addition, APCOA Urban Hubs offer fixed
infrastructure such as the installation of 5G antennas, solar panels and wind energy generation. Our
APCOA Urban Hubs typically require low capital expenditures from us as our partners usually bear the
cost of installation of any required infrastructure. We created APCOA Urban Hubs with the aim of
establishing a new business segment for the use of parking spaces by B2B partners initially with an
increasing B2C offering in the medium term. To date, we have opened 179 APCOA Urban Hubs
focusing primarily on Germany, Denmark and the United Kingdom. As the COVID-19 pandemic has
accelerated the need to find alternative uses for parking spaces, we expect that APCOA Urban Hubs
will be a substantial part of our business going forward, reducing risk by providing further
diversification of our revenue streams. We have recently signed contracts with significant participants
in this evolving market, in addition to pursuing a healthy pipeline of additional Urban Hubs
opportunities.

**Strengths**

We believe that we have several competitive advantages in the car park sector in Europe, including our
local market leadership positions, long-term contract revenues, resilient and diversified business profile,
advanced digital and technology systems, local density and efficient operations and a strong
management team.

**_Leading Parking Infrastructure Operator in Europe_**

We are one of the leading car park infrastructure operators in the European parking market. We operate
approximately 11,700 parking facilities, and have increased our parking facilities from 1.3 million in
2016 to over 1.6 million parking spaces as of March 31, 2021. We believe we have the leading or second
largest market share by number of parking spaces in each of our ten largest markets. Our leading
position helps provide strong brand value, which has allowed us to achieve above-market growth in
recent years in our key countries. Our well-developed operational capabilities provide us with a highly
scalable platform through which we can add additional facilities and services at a moderate incremental
cost. We have been able to efficiently consolidate other European parking operations by acquiring
smaller operators, including Real Estate Schaffhausen GmbH, Alpina Deutschland GmbH, OnePark
A/S, Security Park AS, Profectum AS, Nationwide Controlled Parking Systems Limited, Mobile
Research Solutions Limited and Xpert Parkering Sweden AB. We have a large presence in the top cities
by population in each of our markets, which leads to density-related synergies. Our pan-European
presence allows us to serve our clients across a wide range of European geographies and makes us a
partner of choice for key pan-European property owner and investor corporate accounts. We believe
that our attractive locations, digital offering with direct customer interactions and internal data on
frequencies and customer behavior help us drive favorable pricing.

We are able to use our scale to operate our car park portfolio in an efficient manner, which allows us to
realize synergies and also makes us an attractive partner for our clients. For example, our scale enables
us to share resources among our car parks (in particular, in clusters where we operate multiple parking
facilities in close proximity) including maintenance and supervisory staff, as well as management
resources in respect of parking customer service, client support, accounting, marketing, human
resources, insurance and tax matters. Due to our size and scale, we are better equipped to make
significant investments in IT and parking lot technology and to leverage such investments across our
operations compared to smaller competitors. Our information technology services cover the entire
parking customer experience from searching for and reserving a parking space through to navigating to
the parking garage, contactless entry and exit and electronic payment. In 2018 we launched our APCOA
FLOW platform, which is based on a central, open and scalable digital platform which connects the
vast majority of our leased parking garages, including parking technology, with its customers and their
vehicles via a cloud solution including smartphone apps. We are also in the process of upgrading our
APCOA Flow platform to provide real time data on occupancy and availability of our parking facilities,
thereby enabling us to better anticipate and predict customer demand. APCOA FLOW also provides us
with a direct channel to our end customers, allowing us to offer tailor-made products, differentiated
prices and convenience thereby increasing customer loyalty and frequency of use. These operational
efficiencies and incremental revenues generated through information technology initiatives and
investments allow us to offer a compelling product to customers and landlords. APCOA FLOW is also
a key element of our new APCOA Urban Hubs initiative.

**_Large and Structurally Attractive Growing Market_**

During 2018, the European parking market generated approximately €28 to 29 billion in revenues, with
approximately €11 to 12 billion spent on outsourcing parking management of which over €6 billion was
spent on off-street management in our top six markets. The European parking market grew by 4-5%
annually from 2013 to 2018, primarily as a result of new outsourcing, increased pricing and increased

volume through better utilization and new builds, in particular in larger cities. We expect that
outsourcing will continue to increase as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, as clients seek to lower
their costs by partnering with operators like us who can provide economies of scale and provide
alternative uses such as through our APCOA Urban Hubs initiative. The countries in which we operate
have seen steady parking revenue growth and increasing personal car fleet levels over the past decade.
The large and growing car fleet in Europe included over 240 million vehicles in 2019. From 2013 to
2019, the number of passenger car registrations in Europe increased by between 12 and 15 million
vehicles per year. In 2020 this trend was interrupted by the COVID-19 pandemic. See “Summary—

with a limited number of large players who have the scale to operate their business as efficiently as we

Our client acquisition strategy is largely focused on first time outsourcing. We believe there is continued
strong outsourcing penetration potential in Europe, as currently approximately 50% of the European
parking market by revenue is run by business or property owners and not otherwise outsourced to

outsourcing in parking due to the increased adoption of technologies, the increased consumer demand
for digital services, the increased level of sophistication required in yield management, increased budget
pressure on municipalities and the necessity to decrease costs through economies of scale.
Approximately 80% of our average Pre-IFRS 16 Contract Contribution from new business during 2018,
2019 and 2020 results from first time outsourcing.

We believe that off-street parking is expected to benefit from key trends in the industry, including, for
example: the regulatory shift away from on-street parking with reduced on-street parking provisions in
city centers, increasing prices of on-street parking and the introduction of electric cars, which require
EV charging spaces that off-street parking can offer. As a result, based on the market report prepared
by an international management consultant firm, outsourced parking consumer spend is expected to
grow at a CAGR of approximately 4% between 2018 and 2023.

We also believe that parking facilities will benefit from the ongoing transformation of off-street car

revenue derived from urban hubs: mobility modality, new technology and services, logistics and
electrification. Modality improvements provide inter-modal and multi-modal transports from one
location. Ride share providers use parking facilities as hubs to provide these journeys, or rent shared
cars, electric scooters or bikes from these facilities. New technology and services involves integrating
proximity and community services from our locations through our digital platform. In addition, in
October 2020 we demonstrated, together with Bosch/Daimler, automated valet parking for vehicles
with autonomous driving capabilities at Stuttgart airport. Logistics services includes using urban
facilities as fulfillment centers for logistics, storage and distribution services, such as Amazon drop
boxes and overnight delivery package storage. Electrification includes providing connected charging
services for EVs, fleet and micro mobility like electric scooters and bikes. We currently provide
consumers access to over 2,000 third-party owned charging stations at our parking facilities, which is
being further expanded.

There are significant barriers to entry for new entrants in the car park industry in Europe, including
required investments in building the required operational know-how and digital infrastructure and the
economies of scale that result from achieving local density. In addition, our long-standing relationships
with our clients enable an ongoing dialogue with them as contracts approach renewal and provide us
with an opportunity to sign pre-emptive renewals usually involving upgrading the parking equipment
in return for a new long-term contract. Our focus on outsourcing, not ownership, allows us to develop
key accounts for whom we operate multiple locations across multiple geographies.

across most of Europe and even our largest market (Germany) only represents approximately 33% of
our total Pre-IFRS 16 Contract Contribution, with five other countries (Denmark, Italy, Sweden, the
United Kingdom and Norway) each contributing approximately 10% of our Pre-IFRS 16 Contract
Contribution in the year ended December 31, 2019. We cover parking facilities for a wide range of
business sectors, such as city and shopping, travel, healthcare & education, events and hospitality, and
parking enforcement. Furthermore, many of our parking facilities are typically not dedicated to a single
institution, business or purpose and are multi-functional, in the sense that they are used by motorists
that visit a variety of locations, whether for work, shopping, other cultural activities or other purposes.
We believe our limited reliance on any single geography, customer base or contract helps reduce our
cash flow volatility. Our top ten car parks represented 18% of our total revenues for the year ended
December 31, 2019, while our largest car park represented less than 5% of our revenue during the same
period. We are highly selective when evaluating contract opportunities and we only provide such
services to the extent that they comply with our margin and profitability criteria.

We operate parking facilities under long-term leases with a typical initial duration of ten to fifteen years,
with an option to extend for another five to ten years mostly at our sole discretion and management
contracts with a typical duration of three to eight years. Our top 100 existing lease and management
contracts (based on weighted average Pre-IFRS 16 Contract Contribution for the year ended December
31, 2019) have an average of approximately 12 years remaining. The average duration for our top 100
contracts (based on weighted average Pre-IFRS 16 Contract Contribution) has increased from 23.5 years
in 2016 to 31.1 years in 2021. We have very low contract concentration, with over 5,900 contracts
across over 11,700 parking facilities. We typically have over 96% annual retention. In addition, on
average, contracts representing only 5% of our total Pre-IFRS 16 Contract Contribution for the year
ended December 31, 2019 are up for renewal in each of the next five years. We benefit from significant
revenue visibility in that more than 90% of our revenue typically comes from contracted car parks prior
to the start of any year and such contracted car parks typically provide a stable and predictable revenue
generation. We have a disciplined and proactive contract renewal framework to maximize retention
while safeguarding profitability.

**_Asset-Light Business Model With a Flexible Cost Base and Optimal Return on Capital_**

We operate our clients’ parking assets through two business models: lease contracts and management
contracts. For the year ended December 31, 2019, our operations under lease contracts generated 76%
of our revenues, and operations under our management contracts generated 24% of our revenues. In
each of these models, we run parking operations for our clients without incurring significant capital
expenditures and through an asset light approach that is flexible and scalable, because we operate the
facilities as opposed to owning them. Our asset light model benefits from an attractive payback period
of approximately one year on new business investments, mainly in parking and equipment technology.
Our long-term underlying contract structures provide visibility and stability and we seek to negotiate
for contractual flexibility in the event of material adverse changes on sites that are outside of our control.
For the facilities we operate under leases, we generate our fees based on tariffs charged directly to car
park users, which allows us to apply our yield management expertise to increase volumes and prices.
We have a balanced level of fixed lease costs (42% of fixed rent as a percentage of total rent in the year
ended December 31, 2019 on a pre-IFRS 16 basis) because most of our leases provide for a mix of fixed
and variable rent payments, the variable portion of which is based on the actual revenue earned by us
at the location subject to the lease. For the year ended December 31, 2019, 58% of our €345 million of
pre-IFRS 16 rent expense was variable rents. In the year ended December 31, 2020, when our business
was adversely affected by the COVID-19 pandemic, the variable rents provided an immediate expense
buffer with our variable rent expense decreasing by €111 million compared to our original budgeted
variable rent expense for the period. In the year ended December 31, 2020, 46% of our pre-IFRS 16
rent expense was variable. The management fees charged by us under our management contracts
typically increase each year in line with inflation, and often include additional incentive fees depending
on the performance of the facility. Compared to the substantial decrease in our lease contract revenue
due the COVID-19 pandemic, our management contract revenue during the year ended December 31,
2020 only decreased by 10% compared to the previous year, as our clients continued to need our
services and were required to make payments despite lower parking volumes.

**_Strong Financial Profile, with Successful Management Execution resulting in Growth, Profitability_**
**_and High Cash Conversion_**

Our business model provides us with long-term cash flow visibility as a result of our strategic focus on
operating our facilities through long-term contracts, recurring business through seasonal parking
customers, parking playing a central role in the local economy as well as our ability to accurately
estimate our revenue and profitability and analyze trends in working capital and capital expenditure.
Our long-term cash flow visibility is furthered by the favorable and stable regulatory environment in
the markets in which we operate as well as by certain contractual protections for us in our lease and
management contracts.

Between 2015 and 2019, we achieved 20 quarters of consecutive year-on-year profit growth up to the
end of 2019 (measured on the basis of Pre-IFRS 16 Contract Contribution). Parking demand in a
particular market is typically correlated to the total size of the car fleet in that market (rather than GDP),
which enhances the stability of our revenues over long periods and helps provide resilience through
periods of economic downturn. Our revenue has benefitted from positive structural trends such as
increasing motor vehicle fleet in our markets, a move from on-street parking to off-street parking and

**Strategy**

Our key strategies are as follows:

**_Increase Like-for-Like Sales at our Existing Facilities_**

We plan to continue to seek to increase like-for-like growth at our existing facilities by increasing
volume, effectively managing pricing, creating a differentiated parking experience through digital
parking tools and targeted marketing campaigns. Dynamic pricing has developed as an important
instrument to optimize pricing and yield, and we plan to continue to refine our pricing mechanisms.
Depending on various factors such as day of the week, time of day, occupancy or specific space location
and size, parking tariffs can be dynamically adjusted at car park and specific space level. We plan to
continue to seek ways to manage demand at the individual car park level through efficient pricing as
we believe dynamic pricing offers significant revenue enhancement potential.

We plan to continue to implement measures that seek to create a seamless customer experience. We
have invested in ANPR and our APCOA FLOW mobile application, allowing frictionless and ticketless
entry, exit and payment. Besides automatic number plate recognition, customers can access our sites
through radio-frequency identification (“RFID”), Bluetooth or quick response (“QR”) codes. In
addition, we have installed several user-friendly information technology applications to enhance the
customer experience at our car parks, including electronic payment devices. We have installed cashless
and contactless payment mechanisms and have begun using differentiated parking tariffs based on
supply and demand. Over 3 million customers have downloaded our apps to benefit from this increased
convenience. We plan to continue to implement these initiatives at more of our parking facilities and to
continue to develop new ways to make our parking facilities more attractive to customers.

**History**

APCOA was founded in 1949 in Ohio as the Airport Parking Company of America, Inc. In 1966, ITT
Corporation acquired the company. Subsequently, in 1970, APCOA Autoparking GmbH was founded
in Germany under ITT’s German division, beginning APCOA’s operations in Germany and Austria.
Over the next three decades, APCOA expanded across Europe, entering key markets such as the United
Kingdom (1981), Italy (1985), the Netherlands (1989), Poland (1998), and Belgium (1998). In 1991,
ITT Corporations spun off APCOA’s European operations in a management buy-out financed by
venture capital company CWB Capital Partners. In 1995, the Group listed on the Frankfurt, Düsseldorf
and Stuttgart Stock Exchanges. In 1999, a majority of the company’s shares were acquired by
Salamander AG. The same year the company entered the Norwegian, Swedish and Danish markets. In
2002, EnBW-AG purchased Salamander AG, and subsequently APCOA was delisted from the
Frankfurt Stock Exchange in 2003.

In 2004, Investcorp acquired 98.3% of APCOA Parking AG’s shares from EnBW AG through its
Parking Holdings GmbH entity. In 2005, the company changed the name of Parking Holdings GmbH
to APCOA Parking Holdings GmbH. By the end of 2005, the company was delisted from the Düsseldorf
and Stuttgart Stock Exchanges. In 2007, Eurazeo acquired APCOA Parking Holdings GmbH, and that
same year the company founded its subsidiary in Ireland.

In 2014, APCOA implemented a reorganization of its capital structure through a UK scheme of
arrangement, resulting in the Sponsor becoming the controlling shareholder of the Group.

**Our Services**

We provide our clients with a broad range of parking management services, parking enforcement
services and ancillary services.

**_Parking Management Services_**

Our parking management services focus on the operation of public and private parking spaces and
parking garages. We provide parking management services as either a leaseholder of the parking facility
or an owner- or leaseholder-appointed operator. In the year ended December 31, 2019, we generated
revenues of €720 million from parking management services.

_Lease Contracts_

Lease contracts are our largest contributor to our overall results, representing 76% of our revenue for
the year ended December 31, 2019.

We focus on leasing parking facilities in top-tier locations across urban areas and other areas of high
traffic density in Europe, such as city & shopping, healthcare & education, travel, and events and
hospitality. As of March 31, 2021, our diversified portfolio of parking facilities comprised
approximately 7,000 leased sites in 13 countries, providing for approximately 740,000 parking spaces.
Our lease contracts include a number of car parks with prime locations, such as Verona Cittadella and
Berlin Brandenburg Airport. Many of these locations are in highly transited areas that attract a large
number of visitors for a variety of purposes and have limited free or paid alternative parking options.

Through our lease contracts, we serve a diverse group of real estate owners and leaseholders, including
private individuals, family offices, institutional investors, pension funds and local authorities. Our
clients own or lease the parking facilities and partner with us for the provision of parking management
services.

Pursuant to our lease contracts, we are responsible for collecting the parking fees directly from
consumers and our revenue is equal to the consumer spend at the parking site. As a result, we seek to
maximize yield from the asset through pricing and volume initiatives. We collect parking fees from
consumers either on a time period basis for short-stay tickets (such as per-hour or per-day tickets) or on
a monthly, quarterly, seasonal or annual basis pursuant to subscription agreements. In the years ended
December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, we generated short-term revenues of €356 million, or 53% of total
revenue, €383 million, or 53% of total revenue, and €222 million, or 42% of total revenue, respectively,
and contract parking revenues of €81 million, or 12% of total revenue, €82 million, or 11% of total
revenue, and €87 million, or 16% of total revenue, respectively. We usually have full pricing autonomy
at our parking facilities, except for certain locations such as airports and shopping centers. We generally
determine parking fees based on supply and demand at individual parking locations, taking into account
the local competitive environment. In return, we pay rent to the owner of lessor of the asset on a
monthly, quarterly or annual basis.

We offer our clients a variety of lease contracts, including fixed rent, which provides for fixed rent
payments that are set independently of the revenue generated at the parking facility, variable rent, which
provides for variable rent payments that depend on the amount of revenue generated at the parking
facility, or a mixture thereof. Fixed rent typically includes rent adjustment clauses that are linked to the
consumer price index or similar benchmark indices. For the year ending December 31, 2019, 42% of
our rents were fixed and 58% of our rent were variable (on a Pre-IFRS 16 basis).

Our lease agreements usually have an initial duration of ten to fifteen years, with an option to extend
for another five to ten years mostly in our sole discretion. Typically, our leases include several downside
protection mechanisms, such variable rent arrangements, rent adjustments related to key frequency
drivers (such as the anchor tenant, tenancy percentages of shopping centers, etc.) or related to traffic
restrictions (such as roadwork, renovation work in garages, diesel/car ban, congestion/tolling, etc.), and

##### 131


-----

termination rights in case of revenue dropping below a certain threshold. In addition, additional costs,
including for energy, taxes and maintenance, are typically capped.

Under our lease agreements, we frequently provide, pay for and own, the car parking technology, such
as barrier systems and payment machines, and are responsible for running the parking operations at our
client’s facilities. In addition, we are responsible for all site-related operating expenses, such as
personnel expenses, cost of materials and other operating expenses as well as any site-related capital
expenditures. Our leasing model requires minimal capital investment, which is mainly spent on parking
technology. Our lease agreements have a typical capital expenditure payback period of one to two years.

We typically operate our parking facilities on a 24-hour a day/seven-day a week basis. Most of the
features of our parking facilities are automated, including entry and exit controls and ticket machines.
Consumers can obtain information about subscriptions and tariffs online, over the phone and onsite at
our parking facilities as well as through our digital offering APCOA FLOW. In addition, consumers
can pre-book parking spaces through our websites. We staff and operate parking facilities subject to
lease contracts with our own employees. Upon request from our clients, we also assist with site
development during the building phase as well as the preparation of site operating concepts with
individual tariffs and on-site support following thorough location analysis.

_Management Contracts_

Management contracts represented 24% of our revenue for the year ended December 31, 2019.

Through our management contracts we provide parking management services to clients who view
parking as a key driver of their core business and want to retain pricing autonomy over the site owned
or leased by them, such as airports, local authorities, shopping centers and hospitals. By using our
services, our clients can achieve higher service quality for consumers and lower operational expenditure
due to benefits of scale that come from engaging a dedicated parking operator.

In a typical management contract, our client owns the parking facility, makes the strategic decisions on
tariff policies and quality control, and benefits from the income and service generated through the
parking operations managed by us. We are responsible for running the parking operations, advising the
client on how to drive revenue and providing the car parking technology, which is often purchased
through us but paid and owned by the client. In exchange for our services, we receive a management
fee, which is intended to cover our costs for running a site, in addition to a fee for managing the site,
and is regularly adjusted based on the consumer price index or similar benchmark indices, such as the
London Living Wage, and not subject to parking volumes or consumer spend. In some cases, the
contracts also include a variable incentive fee element based on the amount of revenue generated and
certain other quality indicators.

Pursuant to our management contracts, the owner or lessor of the parking facility is responsible for all
site-related capital expenditures while we are responsible for operating expenses, such as personnel
expenses, cost of materials and other operating expenses. We typically operate the parking facility with
our own employees. Our management contracts require limited or no capital investment.

Our management contracts generally have a duration of three to eight years and include certain
downside protection mechanisms, such as grace periods in case of strikes, regular fee increases
generally linked to the consumer price index benchmark indices, such as London Living Wage, and no
or only very low penalties, with the total penalty amount generally lower than Contract Contribution.

As of March 31, 2021, our management contract portfolio included approximately 4,700 parking
facilities covering approximately 830,000 parking spaces.

##### 132

**_Parking Enforcement Services_**

We offer parking enforcement services to help our clients increase parking compliance and safety and
reduce abuse, over-stays and unwanted parking. These services include the patrolling of parking
facilities owned or leased by our clients, the issuance and collection of parking fines, the management
of bailiffs and the provision of impartial representation and appeals services.

Our parking enforcement services include on-street enforcement for public roads (“On-Street” services)
as well as park and control (“PAC”) or park and guard (“Park & Guard”) services for privately owned
parking facilities. Our clients include local authorities, private parking companies and property owners,
such as restaurants, retailers, hotel chains, and hospitals. In the case of “On-Street” services, the
consumer pays any fines directly to the municipality and we receive a management fee from the owner
of the parking facility. With these contracts, we do not recognize the value of any control fees issued in
our own account. In the case of PAC and Park & Guard parking enforcement services, we collect
parking control fees directly from the consumer and we subsequently may pay a portion of the fees
collected to the site owner. We offer our parking enforcement services mainly in Germany, Austria,
Belgium, Sweden, Norway, Denmark, Poland and the United Kingdom. In particular, our PAC services
in Germany and Austria has increased from generating less than €4 million of our revenue in 2016 to
€20 million of our revenue in 2019.

In the year ended December 31, 2019, we generated revenues of €157 million from parking enforcement
services.

**_Ancillary Services_**

In addition to parking management services and parking enforcement services, we also provide our
clients with an extended range of ancillary services, including valet parking, traffic and taxi
management through our Traffic Management System, trolley management, e-business solutions such
as car park reservation systems (including parking pre-booking, contract parking management systems,
online ticket sales and online marketing measures), advertising space marketing, parking space
monitoring, and security and cleaning services. We also offer consultancy services, whereby we provide
support to landlords and real estate owners by offering advice on conception and planning, marketing
and PR recommendations, design and technology issues, as well as market analysis of customer profiles
and demand. Our support begins as early as the planning phase for new constructions and renovations.
We also conduct feasibility studies to determine the profitability of the project and provide and deal
with the authorities, optimizing processes for architects, developers and planners.

In the year ended December 31, 2019, we generated €57.7 million of our total revenues from ancillary
services.

**Our Sectors**

We provide our services across five sectors: (i) City & Shopping, (ii) Travel, (iii) Healthcare &
Education, (iv) Events & Hospitality and (v) Parking Enforcement, which include our Park & Control
(PAC), Park & Guard and “On-Street” parking enforcement services.

Our clients in the City and Shopping sectors include municipalities, owners and operators of shopping
centers and other retail outlets, investors in office space and other infrastructure. Many of our parking
facilities are typically not dedicated to a single institution or purpose and are multi-functional, in the
sense that they are used by motorists that visit a variety of locations, whether it is for work, shopping,
cultural activities or other purposes. Within our locations we are focused on building local density that
allows us to reduce operational costs given our ability to have a single task force servicing multiple
locations. Many of our rent agreements in the City and Shopping sector include downside protection
mechanisms, related to key frequency drivers (such as the anchor tenant, tenancy percentages of
shopping centers, etc.) or related to traffic restrictions (such as roadwork, renovation work in garages,
diesel/car ban, congestion/tolling, etc.).

##### 133


-----

Our clients in the Travel sector mainly include governments and owners and operators of airports and
railway stations. Several of our airport contracts include ancillary services such as taxi management,
shuttle management, valet parking, trolley services, parking space monitoring, security and cleaning
services. We have long-standing and strong relationships with our key clients in the airport segment.
As a result of the COVID-19 pandemic most of our landlords have agreed to waive any guaranteed
minimum rents in our airport lease contracts, thereby making them fully variable rents and thus
providing downside protection in the face of reduced travel volumes throughout the pandemic. In a
number of locations, our landlords also reduced the variable rent percentages. Our management
contracts in the Travel sector have continued to operate throughout the COVID-19 pandemic, although
some have required lower levels of manpower to service them, resulting in lower management contract
cost recharges to the client, and therefore lower revenues for APCOA, whilst limiting the impact on our
Contract Contribution.

Our clients in the Healthcare & Education sector include public and private hospitals as well as
universities. Many clients in this sector consider parking to be an important service to offer to their
visitors in addition to an important revenue generator for them. As such, we operate a mixture of both
lease and management contracts, depending on the client’s requirements and our view of the risk profile
of a contract. Our healthcare sites are usually characterized by limited available spaces with different
customers to be served: staff, patients and visitors. The efficient management of these customers flows
requires increasingly digital technology. Similarly in the Education sector there is a mix of teaching and
other staff, students and visitors, again with limited spaces that require careful management. Particularly
in the Healthcare sector we increasingly help the hospitals to expand parking capacity by planning and
coordinating the building of new facilities which we then manage through contracts with a duration of
over 15 years. Throughout the COVID-19 pandemic, revenues in this sector have remained more
resilient than other sectors, as healthcare centers in particular remained open and continued to have high
level of car park users (such as for their staff).

Our clients in the Events & Hospitality sector include operators of exhibition and event venues and
hotels (including both sporting and cultural venues). Parking revenues in this sector are highly
dependent on the number of events held or visitors to these locations and our contract and rent structures
reflect the characteristics of each location. Events require substantial ad hoc resources when large scale
events take place, such as the International Mobility Show in Germany or football matches at the
Wembley Stadium in the United Kingdom. We provide these ad hoc resources, organize the car flow,
provide the parking equipment and drive revenue which is largely pre-booked.

**Our Geographies**

We operate our business in 13 countries across Europe. For the year ended December 31, 2019, our top
six key markets (comprising Germany, Denmark, Italy, Sweden, Norway, and the United Kingdom)
generated 84% of our Pre-IFRS 16 Contract Contribution.
