**Interest rate risk**

Interest rate risks arise from changes in interest rates, which can impact negatively on the
financial result and equity of the Group. Interest rate fluctuations can lead to changes in
interest income and interest expense. In addition, they can affect the market value of certain
financial assets, liabilities and hedging instruments. The main objective in managing interest
rate risks within the Group is to keep the net interest result stable. The interest rate and foreign
currency development is monitored at weekly intervals and reported to the Management
Board and the shareholders. Further hedging measures are taken when and if required.

Interest rate risks are presented by means of sensitivity analyses as required by IFRS 7,
which present the effects of changes in the market interest rates on interest payments,
interest income and interest expenses, other components of income and possibly the effects
on equity. Sensitivity analyses are based on the following assumptions:

 - Changes in the market interest rate of original financial instruments carrying fixed
interest rates only affect the result if they are measured at fair value. Accordingly, all
fixed-interest financial instruments that are measured at amortised cost are not
associated with any interest risks pursuant to IFRS 7.

 - Changes in the market interest rate of financial instruments that are deployed as hedging
instruments as part of a cash flow hedge for hedging interest-based payment fluctuations
have effects on the hedging reserve under equity and are consequently taken into
consideration in the equity capital-based sensitivity calculations.

 - Changes in the market interest rate impact on the interest result from original variableinterest bearing financial instruments, whose interest payments are not designated as
underlying transactions in the framework of cash flow hedges against interest risks, and
are consequently included in the calculation of earnings-based sensitivity factors.

If the level of market interest rates had been higher by 100 basis points in the 2019 financial
year, other comprehensive income would have been lower by T€ 334 (previous year: T€ 383)
and the result for the year would have been lower by T€ 2,308 (previous year: T€ 3,884). Had
the level of market interest rates been lower by 100 basis points, other comprehensive income
would have been higher by T€ 368 (previous year: T€ 422) and the result for the year would
have been higher by T€ 0 (previous year: T€ 0).

**Hedging measures – cash flow hedges**

In the financial year under review, the Group had two DKK interest rate swaps (amortising;
previous year 2) to hedge variable interest from lease liabilities. A variable-interest financial
lease liability was designated as the hedged item for the amortising swaps denominated in
DKK. Changes in the cash flow from the hedged items arising from the change in the 3-month
CIBOR rate are compensated for (on a quarterly basis) by the cash flow changes in the
interest rate swaps. The hedging measure is aimed at transforming a part of the variableinterest lease liabilities into fixed-interest lease liabilities and consequently to hedge the cash
flow from the financial liabilities. The amortising interest rate swaps denominated in DKK with
a nominal value of T€ 5,288 (previous year: T€ 6,009) have a residual term until June 2032.

The effectiveness of the hedging relationship is assessed prospectively using the critical
terms match method. As all input parameters that determine the value match, the hedging
relationship is effective. Reasons for ineffectiveness may derive from different credit risks
between the hedged item and the hedging instrument. A regular check is performed to ensure
that credit risk does not dominate in the case of hedged items and hedges. Retrospectively,
a possible ineffectiveness is measured applying the dollar offset method.

**Capital management**

The Group defines its managed capital as the consolidated equity including minority interests.
The goals of capital management include:

 - the possibility to secure the Group’s continuation as a going concern with a view to being
able to continue offering top quality parking space management to customers, and
earnings to investors.

 - to be able to offer investors appropriate income based on the risks that are entered into.

 - having the financial resources that enable the Group to invest in areas that will generate
further earnings for investors.

APCOA PARKING Group's capital management strategy aims to ensure that the group
companies have an equity base that meets local requirements. In addition, financial indicators
(covenants) are agreed for the group in the syndicated loan agreement, which are determined
based on the consolidated figures of the APCOA PARKING Group disregarding effects from
the application of IFRS 16. For this purpose, a pro-forma EBITDA is calculated, considering
both one-time effects and future business development, thus determining a level of gearing
that must not exceed a factor of 7.5. Compliance with these key figures is regularly checked
by the management of the APCOA PARKING Group and the syndicate banks. All externally
imposed capital requirements were met in the 2019 financial year. The COVID-19 pandemic
that occurred in the 2020 financial year has a negative impact on the financial key figures of
the APCOA PARKING Group, which is why the Group has adjusted its forecasts and, on this
basis, the covenants of the loan agreement.

**(46) Events after the balance sheet date**

At the beginning of January 2020, APCOA acquired all outstanding shares of the Swedish
parking operator XPERT Parkering Sweden AB, which manages around 40,000 parking
spaces with a geographical focus on the Skåne region in southern Sweden. The agreed
purchase price for the company was SEK 55 million (T€ 5,265), which was paid in cash by the
Swedish subsidiary APCOA PARKING Sverige AB. In addition, a performance-related
contingent consideration of up to SEK 25 million (T€ 2,393), possibly due until 2021, was
agreed. Further information is currently not available because the purchase price allocation
according to IFRS 3 has not yet been carried out.

In the 2020 financial year, part of the capital reserve was released with the shareholder
resolution of 31 January 2020 in an amount of T€ 90,000, with an equivalent distribution to
Park Luxco 3 S.C.A. This payment to Park Luxco 3 S.C.A. and the related costs were financed
by increasing the existing final maturity loan by T€ 94,000. As part of the same transaction, the
margin for the entire loan was reduced by 0.5% to 3.25%.

On January 30, 2020, the World Health Organization (WHO) declared a Public Health
Emergency of International Concern due to the outbreak of the coronavirus. Since March 11,
the WHO has classified the spread of the coronavirus as a pandemic.

The further course of the spread of the corona virus and the consequences on the business
development of the group are continuously monitored. Based on the latest developments, the
management assumes that the spread of the corona virus and the necessary containment
measures and the associated frequency drops will have a major negative impact on the
Group's business activities and net assets, financial position and results of operations for 2020.
In negotiations with the capital providers on the equity and debt side, the company has
achieved an adjustment of the current capital structure in order to secure the liquidity situation.
For further details, please refer to Chapter (43) Group Risk Management and the Group
Management Report.
